reviewText:
I badly want to play this game to completion but cannot get myself to do it for a few reasons:

One: It's ♥♥♥♥ing difficult on just the normal difficulty... I cannot imagine the impossibility of completing it on the nightmare difficulty without dedicating hours to becoming skilled with the controls and the game mechanics; and I usually will just hop right into a game on one of the harder difficulties in seek of a challenge - I like challenge. What I don't like is seen in reason numero...

Two: THE GAME IS NOT COMPLETE. I enjoy the artistry, the music and the overall idea but besides the difficulty in itself the game has some faults that make it even harder. Such as the fact that gold might as well be useless since you cannot keep your weapons or inventory items after you die. This isn't all that bad though the fact alone will cause some apprehension while playing, especially since the controls are a bit difficult to get used to and in a lot of instances, players will find themselves faced against a multitude of highly-coordinated enemies who will need to be struck many-a-time before they die. This is enough of a challenge alone but if you're killed, you lose all of your items and you need to start from the beginning unless you buy a checkpoint coin...which inevitably ♥♥♥♥s you over as you start in the middle of the map with your default weapons.

Three: Once your main character dies, you're given an alternative soldier character with much less ability to defend himself than your main. This is fine as it encourages a player to revive their main. A HUGE issue is that the soldier cannot always reach the resurrection shrine in order to do so since he can only jump like two feet in the air and in a lot of cases cannot even get around the map himself which, in turn, forces a player to just let him die so that they can respawn with their main... with, do I dare say it again...the default weapons.


Overall I like the concept of the game but I think, like how any great story needs a proofread, this game should've been looked over a few times for any inconsistencies before it was released. I'm thankful I only bought it for a dollar.

reviewText:
This game has some serious technical issues.

I tried to play it, and thru the tutorial, it already had issues with freezes and a sluggish frame rate. The launcher said 32 bits and DirectX 9, while I usually play games on DX 11. I don't think it's an issue with the GPU, apparently it's reloading textures and animations all the time. E.g. if I perform a move, say left block, and then don't use it for 10-20 seconds, the next time I try to use it, the game freezes and then shows the animation at a fast pace. Also, if I pause and resume, the textures go to low resolution and then go back to high resolution... Not sure if this is a feature, it looks more like a bug.

Can't recommend it, I wasn't able to even play it.

reviewText:
I hate writing negative reviews, so I’ll try to keep this as nice as possible.

I tried really hard to like this game, but there are some major issues.

The main issue I have are the controls, i should be able to hold left/right and attack and have the character still move slightly in that direction in order to keep up with the enemy being knocked back, instead u end up hitting an enemy 1-2 times then stopping attacking and leaving ur self vulnerable while u move a step forward again to attack. Next is the ranged combat, the inability to aim the ranged skills in any direction is absurd when u add in the fact u give us flying enemies...

The art is nice, the dialogue is great and the sound is phenomenal. I like the simple storyline but the combat is the bulk of the game and u guys really screwed it up.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Beautiful looking backgrounds, character design and monsters
- Randomized levels
- Great music

Cons:
- Clunky controls
- Characters movments are awkward and leave lots of vunerable openings to get hit
- Enemies have a lot of invincibility frames
- Roguelike aspects that usually make games enjoyable but hurt this one
- On Day 1, you CANNOT customize your gamepad buttons.

Overall the game looks great and sounds great.  And paying only $9.99 didn't make it a bad deal.  The problem really arises with the controls and how the characters fight, as they are clunky and rather slow.  And many times I found myself at the end of an animation getting hit.  While I imagine this is what the designers were going for, it's not something I enjoy dealing with.

When you die, you take over as a human who for the most part is weaker than your main character.  The novelty of this wore off pretty quick.  So in a way, this game is very much a rogue-like.  I admit I wasn't expecting this, and usually playing a rogue-like is pretty enjoyable but in this game it took away enjoyment from the experience.

And why is it that they didn't give you the ability to customize the buttons on the controller???

Overall it isn't a bad game and will be hit among those who like rogue-likes.  But in my overall opinion, I wouldn't recommend this game to people unless you were getting it really cheap in a bundle or you love rogue-likes and super smash brothers controls.

And it looks like they did give you the ability to change your key bindings on controllers and gamepads.  So I thank them for taking care of that in a week 1 patch.

reviewText:
Great idea, poor realisation - a rogue-like mixed with a brawler, sounds good, doesn't it? Well it does, until you actually get to play this game. The big part of great brawling mechanics is having tight and responsive controls, great animations and overall satisfying feel of combat. This game has only one thing going for it - good animations, everything else is quite lackluster, the controls feel unresponsive and way too sluggish. Probably they were going for a tactical feel of combat, where you have to time everything right and avoid button-mashing, but it really doesn't work out. When you face 1 or 2 enemies at the same time the combat is bearable at best, but anything above that is a cluster♥♥♥♥ and it gets really frustrating really fast.
That's already enough to NOT recommend it, because combat was clearly the main focus of this game, and they failed to deliver, but there are some more things that keep me from recommending it:
Shallow level tiles - levels look bland and very repetitive, the level design overall is poor as well
Death mechanic - when you die you get to play as a support character, which is even more clumsy and awkard to control and you're basically stuck with it until you die for real
Play long enough, you can overpower anything - I mentioned how the combat in this game is bad, well... It's doesn't actually matter, if you play long enough - you can just accumulate enough levels and gold to power through most of the levels, which makes it more of a grind
3D on 2D planes looks bad - maybe it's just me, but i don't really like the look of 3D models on plain backgroundsNow there are some good things going for this game: interestying art style, theme, good character design, interesting enemies, enemy capture mechanic is fun to play with.
So, overall, the awkward feel of the combat is enough alone to not recommend it, I did not enjoy my time with this game.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game because the music, graphics and characters are very well done. Once I start an attack, I have to wait until the animation is done before I can turn.  Meanwhile the enemies are all around me.  Jumping in unprecise too.

So overall I wouldn't recommend it.  Sorry...  a waste of potential.

reviewText:
I've played it alone and with a friend, and I've enjoyed the game so far. It reminds me of the Adventure mode from Smash Bros, but randomly generated every time. It's random in the sense that the map layout changes, and the level setup changes. You will encounter a lot of the same enemies throughout the game, but there is a decent amount of them to make it not feel too repetitive. You will also experience a specific level type multiple times in a playthrough (as in you will probably do an ice level a few times).

The combat is also in the style of Smash Bros, but has less moves. Since I'm a big Smash Bros fan, this actually made the controls feel a bit clunky because I would expect to do a certain move, but instead did nothing. It's not really a bad thing, just confusing at first. I feel like there could be more moves and combos though. It's not the best combat in the world, but it's completely fine after playing with it for a little while.

One of my biggest complaints is friendly fire. There is no option to turn this off, and it makes co-op very difficult. My friend killed me almost the same amount of times as the enemies, and it wasn't on purpose. Since you share a screen in a small area, it's too hard to fight a group of enemies with a friend and not hurt them as well. There needs to be an option to disable friendly fire.

A lot of items are crazy expensive at the vendors, so you will have to save up your gold. You can also find items from chests, which has been the easier thing to do so far. I feel like saving up gold is a challenge, and it's very possible that it could go to waste if you buy an item and die early on. Health orbs from enemies barely give you HP, and I think they could use a bit of a boost.

If you are a fan of rogue-like games, you should get this game. It is easily worth the price. I hope they continue to update the game with more content and maybe more combat mechanics. You should grab a friend to play with too, even though they might end up killing you on accident.

reviewText:
It's a shame that the really very bad parts of the game make it impossible for me to recommend the game.
Visually it is fantastic, but game design wise the stupid decisions haunt the experience.
The game mechanics of the fighting are poorly introduced, the pacing of more difficult encounters feels random.

I get it that this is supposed to be a hard game and this was clear to me when I bought it.
But when a game has a steep learning curve, then a really annoyingly punishing system like the one in place is inexcusable:

You'll die (quite often in my case, because it was really hard for me to adapt to the unusually sluggish controls) and instead of respawning, you get replace by a soldier with even worse agility and abilities. This guy then needs to find a sparse statue to revive you (never found one) or if he dies as well, you'll start at the village and the descent begins again.

I'm voting this down because it is not only not a good game, but it is also saddening me how much potential has been wasted by ACE team once more.
I struggeled through zeno clash for many hours, even though I hated the game play. But I loved the fresh fantastic world so much that I endured it's flaws. I was prepared to do this again, but this time I won't.
Hire a Game Designer and some QA next time!

reviewText:
Abyss Odyssey is a fighting game dropped into a rogue like dungeon crawler.
With that in mind, this review will concetrate on comparing Abyss Odyssey to other games in the fighting genre.

Although unique in many ways, the basic fighting system takes a lot from the Street Fighter series.  Athough there are no command inputs, like quarter circles on the joystick, the movement feels a lot like Super Street Fighter.  The combat system is not build around flashy air combos and button smashing; instead it focuses on simple strikes, a few special moves and tight hit boxes where timing is everything.

Along with this familiar focus on timing, the developers also were wise enough to borrow some of the more familiar ways players take advantage of timing in Street Fighter.  Knockdowns, cancels, blocking, keep-away techniques like uppercuts and projectiles (think Ryu/Ken), wall juggling, as well as super moves that stop the animation for a moment were all welcomed discoveries for me.  Fighting games are of a special genre where dexterity and muscle memory actually matter, and when one is disguised as a rogue like adventure game or platformer like Abyss Odyssey might be, it can easily be unfairly compared to the wrong games.

As a fighting game, this gets a solid A-.  It's not fantastic, but it is rather good.  The turn-around animation is a bit slow and too long horizontally for some characters which make it frustrating to face the enemy in narrow places.  There also seems to be a lot of ways to break your block, which makes blocking less useful than it should be.  The AI is very smart and ramps up in difficulty nicely - although I do wish I could change the general game difficulty through the UI.  Nitpicks aside, this is the best $15 I've spent in a while - and I haven't even tried the multiplayer yet.  It’s beautiful, the rouge/dungeon crawling is light and fun, and it even has community based goals that will unlock more content.

If you like fighting games, this one is solid and unique enough not to pass up.  If you are not a fan of the genre however, the learning curve might be a bit too steep, but it also might be one of the more fun fighting games to learn on given it has so much more content  to enjoy.

reviewText: I was kind of excited about this game and it turned out well, but honestly was disappointing in many ways as well. Before you read further, let me sum it up with a I give it a 6/10... So not a standing ovation, but not terrible either. The 2D art used in the game is wonderful and the characters they create are interesting and varied in this world that had so much potential. I honestly enjoy the 3 playable characters and their assortment of foes especially the devil. However, the game needs serious work; it does not feel like a fleshed out game at all. The maps are relatively stale (usually about 3-4 backdrops) and somewhat small, the creatures you fight are not varied as well and while some are well designed and are great to play as, most are not. In fact, if you can capture the spirit of the bird with the spear just right click and kill most AI in the game without challenge. The bird as well as the skeleton with the sword and the uppercut special are OP and kind of the only useful enemy spirits. As for the actual characters, the main fencer woman is nice but clunky to control till you get her specials. The hooded monk is nice but I haven't played him out yet. The female water god is OP with her axe, but her jelly fish special is completely worthless (you'll find out and quickly trade it out for melee specials). The weapons you find for the characters are horribly mundane and not varied. Most of the time you will not find a better weapon for your character and the levels on the weapons go up to about 3 (when your character can exceed lvl 30+). The game also has kind of low replay value. If they add to this game, flesh out the world, spruce of the character textures and add more variety, this game will be great, but as it stands, its a nice shade of mediocre.

reviewText: Fantastic game, and beautiful in art and sound to top it off. Feels like a rogue-lite beat-em-up featuring fighting game elements. The flow of combat in this game takes some getting used to, and will almost definitely feel sluggish and unresponsive at first. However, I noticed that this feeling disappeared after spending around two hours in the game. The different playable characters all feel unique with different play styles. The game does come off as a little on the easy side, but the procedural generation of the dungeon combined with the ~37 different possible transformations/characters increase the replayability. To top it off, the developers have stated that additional content (enemies, transformations) will become available as players, globally, defeat the final boss. I utilize a controller for playing this game, and would definitely suggest one to any potential players. I cannot speak to the effectiveness and responsiveness of keyboard and mouse control, as I have not tried that control scheme.

reviewText:
It's not often I rate games down but I can't help but address this one. Not because it's bad per se but because it has so much potential to be great.

PROS:

- Fantastic Soundtrack. I only wish you didn't have to own the game to buy it first. I'd pay the price of the game for the soundtrack alone. I will look around to see if I can find it elsewhere, though.

- Unique Artstyle. While I admit I'm not a big fan of the character or creature models art style, it is still different. So, I give it credit there for not looking like everything else out there.

- Interesting story from the little bit I've seen. I'd like to see the rest but since I won't be finishing the game that's not going to happen.

- Great presentation. The menus and interface are all very well designed and put together. Everything flows pretty well as it should in any dungeon crawler like this.

CONS:

- Art Style. This one is strictly opinion but even though the art style is different than most, it's still pretty ugly in terms of the characters and even the environments at times.

- Combat: One thing that's extremely vital in a game like this is good fliud combat. It's just not here. Don't get me wrong. You can have a decent game with stiff controls but considering most of your characters aren't exactly power" characters
date: you might expect them to be a little more limber and agile. The animations are nothing to boast about and considering this is a core game mechanic
recommended: it's a big hit to the games playability.\n\n- FRAME RATE: Considering my machine is powerful enough to run Bioshick Infinite

This could really be a masterpiece almost but it just falls short.

I'd recommend Outland

reviewText:
This game has some serious, SERIOUS flaws.


Ok, lets start with movement and combat. the levels were designed with the highest movement characters in mind, not the lowest. So trying to catch jumps and move with a lesser charcter is infuriating with this game. Some characters just outright don't grab ledges and i find that mechanic frustrating EVERYONE OR NO ONE! The combat goes from too easy to way too difficult and swings wildy back and forth in each zone. Doesn't really have a good flow and feel to it.

Item balance is also a serious issue with the camp tokens costing way too much for what they are.

I love the artwork and the story but this is going to be a challenge and a half to get anywhere close to beating.

With some tweaks this could have been an amazing title, but they didn't so it's not.

reviewText:
TL;DR
Graphics are reasonably nice, but the controls aren't much to write home about except in an angry letter. Lack of real teaching tools for a new player makes it difficult to get into without having to memorize the keyboard shortcuts from the beginning instead of gradual learning.

Maybe me playing this game with a less than ideal computer was a mistake and somewhat lessens the truthfullness of my review, but no matter. I simply didn't find the game enjoyable.
I understand the game is inherently angled to people who like challenge, who want to be thrust into something and learn to conquer it themselves. But the fact I had to keep breaking flow in order to work out what ♥♥♥♥ing button did what (by going to the control menu) just sorta pisses me off. A game of this nature relies on flow, and if I can't keep that flow going because I don't know how the play the game, you're maybe doing it not too great for some of us.
And the sheer speed the enemies move (coupled with low framerate from aformentioned ♥♥♥♥ computer) made it impossible for the game to feel natural. Something about clicking being the method of attack threw me off as well. Hearing my mouse rapidly click clack away as I tried to hit a skeleton just wasn't doing it for me.
The graphics look reasonably nice though. Perhaps the game is more enjoyable with a controller and a good pc. Perhaps pigs fly. Perhaps the fact I played for 8 minutes cheapens the opinion of the review. I don't care, didn't enjoy, would rather go play Symphony of the Night on an emulator.

reviewText:
Abyss Odyssey can be summed up in one word entirely.

Clumsy.

The controls of Abyss Odyssey are clunky and unmanagable. Characters hardly jump when you want them too, their movements are sudden and make me feel like I'm leading a lead brick through a side-scrolling dungeon.

While jumping, you have little if any control of how far and how high you jump, and especially where you land. When the characters do jump, they feel as if they're jumping with a ton of bricks on their back.

The keyboard commands are also confusing and use minimal customization. If you want one key to jump and go up" at the same time
date: you can forget it. What does "UP" Even mean? It's a side-scroller for god sake. UP means JUMP.\n\nThe combat system is clumsy and uncoordinated. The concept of blocking and dodging are completely lost to the fact that they're completely useless unless you block for long periods and then spam the dodge key away from enemies

reviewText:
One of the best games I've ever played.
The music is great, the graphics are awesome, the atmosphere is really good. It's similar to Binding of Isaac, but has different fight system (I like this one better), and has better graphisc, and this is not funny.

The fighting is responsive for me, everyone says it's not. After dark souls it has great controls.
It's hard, that's good too. And the random generated maps *.* You need luck and much more skill to advance. And if you don't advance.. not a problem, you can always try again.

And after you die you have a second chance as a soldier! I ♥♥♥♥ed in my pants it was that great! Awesome game, addictive, sadly not enought players online at midnight to play with me, but with friends it's infinite fun.

100/10 recommend!!

reviewText:
The only positive of this game so far is how good it looks.
Literally effortless port from console to PC, they haven't bothered to implement *anything* for PC users. Everything is laid out for an xbox controller and all the buttons on screen are for xbox.

Everything is just unfun right now. Enemies wait under you while jumping, have very weird and inhuman ways of fighting you which means you need to cheese it as a soldier most of the time. (The soldier is the back up character which you get when you die, and this WILL happen when you get hit, you often get chained for 100% of your HP)

Sluggish, boring combat, never quite sure what the aim is. Rarely do I buy a game where I can say very little positive about it, but this is quite frankly the worst game purchase I ever made, and I never thught I would enjoy Euro Truck Sim 2 more than another game.

reviewText:
A fighting game in which you have to actually fight, not just smash buttons.
It's fun and it kept me thinking about it when i was away from the computer, i guess im hooked!

Controls are not sluggish, they are cleverly designed to limit you (at the start, things get smoother as you get stronger) to pay attention to your next move, if you push buttons mindlessly you will fail, if you block, dodge, parry, and learn to recognize the opportunity to hit, you will do fine and have fun, thats what video games are about afterall, not about loot, nor vanity items, nor special edition hats, nor anniversary items nor founders" badges
date: they are about enjoying the process of playing
recommended: and that is what Abyss Odyssey is about."

reviewText: So I buy the game because it lists Co-op. I can get over the beautiful and clunky animations, as the enemies seem to suffer the same handicaps. Then I find out that you don't get true co-op because if you turn off friendly fire it acts like you've turned on cheat mode and disables story progression. Ever since Contra on the grand old NES has Friendly Fire been an accepted loss with co-op modes...because while the story plays out in a 2D side scroller, we know the world itself is actually 3D. So with the loss of a standard of co-op gaming goes my recommendation.

reviewText:
This game man... This game.

Abyss Odyssey is a 2-Dimensional dungeon crawler/rougelike. It looks good(Both in trailer and graphics) but is horrible to play. Just as a note i played with a keyboard not a controller.

First lets talk about the UI. It is the thing that killed this game the most for me. It SUCKS. To figure out most buttons I had to go to the controls menu. The UI its just looks... bad. Its mostly just brown-ish yellow-ish paper. Which I get it is in the 1890's but.. still. It looks bad.

Gameplay its self is not only annoying but un-intuitive. You have (in the beggining) a grand total of 4 moves. 2 of which are DEFENSIVE. I get you 'build it up as you go along' but seriously? 2 fighting moves? SERIOUSLY? Another thing is you start of as a character that can only use one-handed weapons, and I personally came across 4 really cool looking weapons that I COULDN'T PICK UP.

Graphics and sound is good. Not the best, but it doesn't put your eyes and ears in agony. Its actually quite nice.

Now time to grade!

UI: 3/10
Gameplay: 4.25/10
Graphics: 8/10
Sound: 7.4/10

OVERALL: 4.3/10 and therefor a Thumbs DOWN.

reviewText:
I thought at first that i was bad at the game and needed to get used to the controls. Problem is, its not just the controls.
This game is very porrly made, it has a horrible AI which will outnumber and ♥♥♥♥ your bumhole, and very sloppy controls even for controller. On top of that not only when you die the first time you get a character with a completely different moveset and you lose everything if that character dies, exept for money. Every item you bought (which have insanely high prices for this kind of game) is lost if your second character dies. Its like this game WANTS a bad review.

So, lets post the - and + of this game.

+ .) 1.) Multi-player (which is very much needed for casual players)
2.) Interesting Lore.
3.) PvP.
4.) NPC allies (sometimes)

- .)   1.) bad voice acting for most NPC's.
2.) Lose every iten you bought after 2 deaths.
3.) Terrible AI.
4.) enemies usually out number you.
5.) bad community (people that dont know the game's controls and people that attack you when you want to co-op)


So, all in all, i didn't get very far through the game so i can't tell you all the Negatives and Plus's
But, in my time playing these types of games, i've never seen such a poorly made game in my life.

If this game compelles you, go ahead buy it or try it out in the next three days as it is F2P till then But, do not be dissapointed when you see sloppy controls, terrible AI etc.

reviewText:
I, like most of the negative reviewers, had a problem with the control's.  They are just too damn clunky.  Fighting is more frustrating than fun.

The one good thing about this rogue-LITE, are the graphics.  The game looks very differant than most 2D brawlers.  This still can't save the game from terrible gamepad control's.  I beat the game in about 3 hours.  For 15 bucks that doesn't seem like it's worth the money.  Well you say, go level the other 2 characters and you'll artificially inflate the game time.  Yes this is true.  But when the combat is so frustrating for some characters, such as the monk, then I just cant endure it.  I just want to rage every time I play the monk becasue his attacks are so slow and his specials require space.

I must be terrible at the game because the biggest combo I can muster is 4 hits.    There are just too many monsters on screen and too much going on for me to think effectively.  The monsters give you plenty of time on the easy levels to think out a strategy.  But most of the time it's just button mashing your specials.  There is definately some skill involved.  So if you're bad at fighting games, then avoid Abyss Odyssey.

As a game by itself. It isn't bad.  It is just VERY short. I honestly wish I could refund but as I said it took me 3 hours to beat the first time.

reviewText:
Haven't been able to tolerate more than 5 minutes of that game, might go back later...

Superb example of what not to do in the first instant of a video game. Beautiful characters looking totally  lame and impotent!  Let's start with basic combat ommisions, can't turn around in combat, attack are planted stiff on spot, can't interrupt attack, even with blocking. Can't interrupt hits received.

Then I activate good old couch coop! Be advised : FRIENDLY FIRE IS FULL ON! So your only coop strategy is to take enemies in a sandwich. Both character are also visually identical so it's part of the puzzle. And the enemies fight beautifully, to our demise. In five minutes I've beend introduced to at least 5 - 6 different enemy types that I couldn't humanely decode. You'll face butt kicking traps with infinite health for tutorials, they even have to play a silhouette of the character mimicking the solution and even then I'll tell you, you have to dodge in the air. And watch out for the swinging axe's return XD hilarious!

Was just the first minutes, I'll go back into it because I think it's a great learning experience. But after those first few fighting humiliations and confusing level design, we put down the controller just disgusted and wanting to do something better with our time. It might as well be an awesome game like I've been taught by Dark souls or Divinity, tho I doubt it, we'll see...

reviewText:
This game is unfinished. It's from indie dev ACE but publisher ATLUS who brings Persona, Fire Emblem, and Shin Megami, so is it really indie? Indie seems tacked on meant to excuse the shoddy game.

DESIGN:
The nobody policeman pop in if your main character dies and they're the most memorable imagery in the game. They don't even get names but their art is all that stands out. The character art is alright but it's filler image that goes in and out just as quick. It might be more interesting if the level design were better but everything is drab and blends in except the policemen. I feel like I was half asleep while playing the game because it was so hard to pick out any details. The treasure boxes, the platforms, even the characters meld together so it's difficult to know what's background and what's interactable.

The jumps are (intentionally?) leaden so while you have a double jump, it rarely does much good. Trying to platform onto some of the moving ledges makes me more frustrated than Guacamelee's time warp/wall jump BS, and yet the punishment is 200 off your health. Three or four misses take half your health while enemies drop little orbs that replenish only 50. The actual fighting is boring and basically button-mashing, except you have to use the sticks so it's just stick wobbling. If there's a strategy, it's not apparent.

There's something to be said for a game that doesn't hold your hand in today's world of hour long tutorials and mobile games, but Abyss Odyssey teaches you--slowly--how to attack, jump, run, and dodge. Each of these are simple button presses that have to be figured out prior to the game prompt. However, nothing else is explained. Are there elemental weaknesses? There are apparently counters. The nuances are left mysteries. I wouldn't be surprised if major mechanics went unnoticed for a month in this game.

Sometimes health bars pop up above the enemies, but only as flashes that show you enemies still have health. How much? It goes by too quickly to tell. If you poison an enemy, a green number appears and counts down. What's this for? Possibly a timer till the enemy is hurt again or until the poison is gone. It doesn't count down in a timely manner though. Each numeric drop takes anywhere from 0.2 seconds to 5.0 seconds.

It touts procedurally generated terrain as a plus, but it becomes forgettable because there's no human touch to it. It's a winding path of dead-ends and sudden fights where you're fenced in until....something happens. It's a mystery as to what. Sometimes one of the three enemies will die and the fences will drop and sometimes you have to kill all of them. Sometimes after a bit of fighting, the walls fall prematurely. It makes sure that none of the playthroughs are the same, and each delve into the depths takes only an hour if you don't die, but they're all such a blur of boring that it doesn't matter that they're different.

There are three characters, but the two I have play identically. They have different weapons and as Katrien, I often find Ghost Monk's weapons or Pincoya's, which can't be picked up even for gold. If I find Katrien's weapon, then it's worse generally. Same goes for while playing as Ghost Monk.

CONTROLS:
I tried my Xbox One controller to start as it's run every other game I've played. The controllers were sluggish and sometimes Katrien wouldn't attack or dodge or whatever. After 20 minutes of that torture, I tried my 360 controller and it worked better but still the X button wouldn't attack reliably. I had to go to the Right Stick to attack anything, which seems to be the intended button, but all the special attacks and jump buttons are mapped to the A, B, and Y so why would I need to switch from stick to button for combos? The Y specials aren't reliable either. To attack, you press up or forward or down and Y, but trying to get the correct one to trigger is about 33% reliable.  There are all these attacks mapped to too few keys and other buttons left unused. It's bearable, but not at all intuitive. Maybe the keyboard is easier to use.


STORY:
I don't know. You're a dream of the warlock fighting the warlock and if you die, you're reborn with your money and level but not your weapon or items. Maybe it's a Chilean legend as most characters have hispanic names and some have hispanic accents. It often feels like a Japanese name where everyone is named Suzuka or Takashi and the story is just going by without significance or weight for Westerners. There's not much there anyway. Little bits of dialogue. The Warlock and Katrien apparently used to do it in their marital bed, but now she's trying to stop him. After beating it once with Katrien, you unlock a Ghost Monk who uses a different weapon. He's death or something. It doesn't make sense.

reviewText:
Levels are boring. They are all square block mazes. And they're not even hard mazes (logically). Sometimes the game screws you over and you cannot reach a certain point because it's too high (even with crouch-jump when possible).
Often the sluggish controls prevent you from moving in the direction you want to go or from grabbing onto a ledge or from landing on a platform.

Combat is sluggish and cancel points don't renew over time. There is no telegraphing of enemy moves either.
You best option is to discover bad patterns in the enemy's AI such as dodging right into a low sword attack after you fire a projectile into them. Often you can face away and just do a crouching attack which just kinda rolls back and hits them.
Basically the combat is not fun. It's too sluggish to control, and you resort to exploits which is not fun either.

To sum up, control is not fun (moving and attacking), exploration is not fun, there is no action, it's just not a deep or fun game.

Also, when you defeat a shopkeeper he does not drop the loot he was carrying.
Why is there an option to attack him when it's a waste of time?

reviewText:
tl;dr: The combat is laudable but still unsatisfying. The feel is off and there's little room to demonstrate superior skill against the enemies because they are all playable characters and thus can do anything you can. The dungeon and story are charmless. Interesting game, worth a taste, not a classic.

I dream of battling huge steroided up jerks. The huge guy lets out a roar before his swing, I dodge, counter attack, he flashes before I finish my combo, I dodge out of it just in time to avoid a fearsome counter-attack. Really, give me an attack button and a satisfying dodge roll and I am a happy camper in most games.

Actually, scratch that, turns out I need a bit more than just Attack and Dodge. Odyssey has both in spades and it is not quite enough for me.

Odyssey is a side-scrolling brawler roguelike-ish game with a random dungeon and permadeath and all the usual fixin's as well as persistent XP growth and move collection and what-not, the usual sort of thing you expect of the recent indie action roguelike trend. The combat is somewhere south of Smash Bros and east of Bloodrayne Betrayal (Only not nearly as awful.) Your moveset is limited, attack+direction, special+direction, but there is some combo potential here, though a lot of the fighting feels a little stiff and wooden. Watching enemies get up is a Chilean passtime, it seems; you'll do a lot of that. You have a limited number of dodge cancels before they have to recharge (See Valdis Story only less cool.) and can become pretty much any enemy in the game.

Yep, every single enemy is a playable character, and that actually feeds into a problem I have with the game.

Back to my example at the start, I am reading the boss's attack patterns and reacting. I'm rewarded for learning the system and striking at the right time. The enemies in Odyssey, however, are really all just variations of your character with generally less openly useful moves. They block, dodge (Especially your projectiles), and can attack without warm-up most of the time. This means that you just have to take a lot of unavoidable damage each encounter just because there is no safe way through. Fighting your equals creates a cute dance, but it feels a lot more like battling Street Fighter AI rather than facing down Vergil.

But then there's a reason you're taking all that damage. Between your main character, his/her backup soldier, and the enemy you can morph into, you have three whole life bars. Match this up with persistent leveling and you can more or less kiss balancing goodbye. This will sound like heresy but I cleared the dungeon on my second try. For my reward, I unlocked the second town to start from, though I still have two characters to unlock as well as a third town. I only ever faced one midboss (Though he was absolutely no deviation from the standard enemies in combat style. Even the warlock himself felt like I was back to jump-kicking Akuma over and over.)

I'll definitely go back to the game, but in the end I will likely forget it sooner rather than later.

This Warlock has some really boring dreams, to boot. Everything is muted, murky colors and all the enemies are just kinda ugly dull pitiable mutants.

Also, I have paid minimal attention to the story, and in return it has demanded precious little of my attention. I applaud the minimalist approach, though the huge dreary ugly world down here and all the story hints suggests we're going to be asked to pity that so tragic warlock because it's so dramatic to not have a villain (Really, having a proper villain seems like it would be the most shocking thing some games can do these days, but I digress. That's not Odyssey's problem...). Which actually brings me to a point I don't like about the story: You play as one of the few figments of the warlock's dreams that is not a slavering demon trying to kill everyone. You are not shocked by anything you see because you're a part of it. You can't die either, so you just keep coming back and trying again.

But the soldiers in the game are human beings just trying to fight the monsters of the abyss, protect their families, and when you fall, despite your immortality, they still will swoop in to do their damndest to save you. Hell, in my last clear, the soldier was the one who defeated the warlock (Only to poof out and be replaced by my character for the ending cutscene. What a snub!).

So you are playing an blob of memories with neither a personality nor a stake in this conflict and the people relegated to the sidelines are genuine heroes with personalities and fears who are to the last man engaging in wholly noble and heroic acts of holding the line against hordes of ugly monsters, all afraid, but all driven by duty. Someone at some point thought that it was better to tell the story of the Warlock's childhood trauma or whatever instead of the story of these gents. Good job on that.

If the story is somehow more interesting than NOW ON A VERY SPECIAL EPISODE OF ALL MY WARLOCKS, I welcome hints or even, properly marked, spoilers in the comments if you feel the need to convince me reading rather than playing the game is worthwhile.

reviewText:
So what happens when you take Castlevania Symphony of the Night... or more accurately Castlevania Aria / Dawn of Sorrow and combine it with Dark Souls clunk?

Well let me answer that for you... You get a game about travelling in to a procedurally generated abyss delving deeper and deeper to kill some demon warlock Freddy Kruger guy, who's nightmares are your reality. In fact, you're not even real because he dreamt you up... except you want to kill him... that's what kind of game you get... yeah.

So this game tries way too hard to be epic and it just fails on just about every front. The art style is the only thing this game has going for it and it's just a shame it was wasted on such a giant turd like Abyss Odyssey. It's as if all the production value went in to the art style and none of it in to the game development, plot or music because it was all forgettable.

It's nothing new you haven't already seen, the point being is a lot of the game play mechanics are drab, boring and redundant... let me explain:

It's a rouge like game, where no dungeon you enter is ever the same twice... except that's kind of a lie because every area is almost exactly identical to the last, aside from some buzz saws and flowers trying to kill you.

You basically travel down a linear path and encounter a branching point here and there. These branching paths quickly lead to a dead end with a treasure chest or check point of some kind. Usually when there's nothing there I do what any veteran Casltevania player would do and smack the wall. 20% of the time there's a hidden area with a shop keeper or paltry weapon hiding behind it...

No meat though, I probably would of enjoyed a nice Castlevania roast beef here and there but no... it's usually just some crap.

Another thing about this game is how lazy the direction is... I mean, procedurally generated dungeons for a game with this kind of art style?

With all the effort put in to the art direction you figured they would of came up with some cool level designs and boss design concepts and made an actual game... you know, one where the developers have to always be one step ahead of themselves so players can't sequence break the game... either way it's wasted potential.

The game itself gets dull and tired way too quickly. It has unlockable characters and starting points but you need to rely heavily on luck... Okay basically everything resides on your luck, as well as time put in to the game.

I beat the game once, unlocked some floaty chick with a spear who has a jelly fish for a companion (Yeah is this making you cringe yet? I was rolling my eyes the entire time... what pretentious ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t is this any way?)

There's also a heavy weapon user who looks a lot like Tyrael from the Diablo franchise (because THAT was purely a coincidence) and he's randomly unlocked by beating random bosses you encounter... random, random, random ....so have fun with randomly doing that.

Another thing that bothered me was the limited inventory space ... of 4 whole spaces. Enjoy managing poison antidotes, mana potions, health potions and check point tokens when you can basically only carry 1 of each item.

The number one biggest waste of resources though that made up most of the game's mechanics, or should I say gimmick, was the ENTIRE enemy capture system...

I mean WTF is the point of all this? All the enemies I caught were even clunkier and weaker than my main character.... none of them had any really cool abilites and were all difficult to control... It's as if the developers were saying: Hey switch to this centaur thing if you want to die... like right now... yeah there ya go
recommended: hope that helped."\n\nI never understood why the game forced you in to sequences where you had to play as random enemies either

reviewText:
The only way I can describe this game is abysmal.

You don't get anything for playing: the progression system is shallow to the point that you wouldn't notice it if it weren't there.

Which wouldn't be so bad, but the game itself doesn't offer any real depth.  Sure, it offers that you can play as the enemies, but you only ever get a short series of attacks that are easily interrupted, as all enemies operate on the same mechanics as the player, which leads to many dodges and lots of blocking, resulting in combat ultimately just slowing down gameplay, as you have to get past combat instead of participate in it.

Everything only made worse by mediocre controls.

I'm at a loss to how a publisher backed this title.

reviewText:
If you're looking for a chill out with an indie title, you might want to get this one on the next game sale. Abyss Odyssey is a pretty decent rogue-style, side-scrolling dungeon crawler that can offer a few hours of entertainment.

Enter the Abyss, a constantly changing nightmarish world with every load of your game. Choose among three different heroes, with different weapon-combat styles and spells at their disposal to vanquish the creatures of the Warlock's mind. To add a bit more to the customization, you are able to absorb a slain monster's soul, and make use of its skills to add to your own arsenal.

Combat is quite fluid, and very easy using a game controller. Attacks are composed of simple directional and button combinations. Defensive maneuvers are composed of blocking, jumping and dodging around with the same ease in command. The combats give off a fighting game vibe - the AI is quite formidable at times as the use blocking and dodging as much as you do. (And they have a habit of just popping up around  you in different combinations.)

The game is packaged in a very pleasant art style resembling that of Tarot Cards (Art Nouveau, if you want to sound fancy.) Musical scoring is reminiscent of Castlevania which fans of the genre may find quite enjoyable.

The plot. Well. Don't expect much.

Nothing too fancy or ground breaking really - but it gets the job done with its simple mechanics. I actually haven't finished yet, as I'm still fumbling around with the three different heroes and trying to figure out which one I like the best. I haven't checked out any of the multi-player functions yet but I heard that it's quite good as well.

If you want something laid back, I'd really recommend this for you. My advice, again, get it on a sale day.

reviewText:
I wanted to like Abyss Odyssey.  The combination of fighting games and roguelike elements has been under-represented since the PS1 era. (Hi, Tobal 2's Quest mode.)  Controls that draw from Smash Bros should have meant a maneuverable adventure game, something that should have had little difficulty surpassing Brawl's underwhelming Subspace Emissary mode.

Unfortunately, that is not the game that ACE Team delivered.  I've waited quite a while to see if the game would change before posting my review, but I haven't seen evidence that my opinion will change.

Combat simply feels off, as if it is sluggish or clunky.  Jumping feels floaty and forced.  Aerial moves do not mesh well with jumping.  While the control scheme in its most basic form is designed around the control scheme of Smash Bros, the actual mechanics and maneuverability (and lack thereof) are not.  The game relies on a cancel point system for combos, where you can cancel only if you have a 'cancel orb' available.  Cancel orbs are so important and integral to combat that you should spend your first levels unlocking them instead of upgrading moves, which begs the question of why they weren't unlocked from the start.  People will point to YouTube videos of various combos as examples of how amazing the combo system is, but those combos are almost always impractical within the single-player game itself.

'Replay' consists in no small part of an unlock system that is designed to be a grind-driven time sink.  You cannot just encounter an enemy and defeat it to 'capture' it.  You have to have a full magic bar, and land a killing blow with a special capture move (that drains the bar regardless of success).  If it ended there, it might be acceptable, but the game goes further.  You have to be at a minimum level to capture an enemy, and the required level is heavily artificially inflated compared to the difficulty of the opponent.  The only solution is to grind your level through repeated plays of the same character.  It doesn't  matter that you can beat every enemy in the game when in your low teens for level.  The game will simply not let you capture various enemies until you are level 30, 40 or even 60, even if you have been beating that enemy without issue from the time that your level was a single digit value.

As for level design, Abyss Odyssey unfortunately functions as an example of the shortcomings of relying on procedural generation.  The component parts that the system has to rely upon simply aren't interesting, nor are the final results.

All in all, to some degree I feel a bit sorry for ACE Team.  They obviously tried, but their ambitions may simply have been beyond their abilities and business realities.  (A budget title with fighting game movesets and animations for all player characters and enemies?)

Do I recommend the game? At full price, I find that I cannot.  However, if you do find the concept interesting, and find others say enough positive things, then perhaps consider buying it when it is at a good sale price.  At worst, you might find a disappointing title.  At best, you might find it a hidden gem that you will continue to play.  I, unfortunately, fell into the former category.  Others have obviously fallen into the latter.

reviewText:
I recommend this game but barely.,I must admit that I wasn't sold on the gameplay videos. I just didn't grab me or look exciting. I remember watching them and being unimpressed by them, but the thought of a street fighter/smash bros style dungeon crawler was pretty irresistable. I ended up buying it cos It was cheap.

People complained in the reviews that the coop is stupid because you can't turn friendly fire off, well, they patched that so if you want to play the game with an 8 year old then that now becomes viable... and fun.

The gfx are good, the sound is ok (I don't know who would want to buy the music - bleugh), some of the monsters are pretty cool but I think a lot of them have weird moves and aren't very smooth. I think the gameplay is responsive enough but here is my biggest gripe : The combos don't work from training mode. I loved Marvel vs Capcom 3 because of the awesome, fun combos you can do consistantly. Abyss Odyssey includes a training mode that you can practice combos, but the problem is that the advanced combos that work on the training dummy don't work on the monsters in the game (at least not for me). That training dummy juggles easily but my dash-cancel jump combos just wiff on the in-game monsters. There also doesn't seem like there are enough moves per character. The supporting characters feel really restricted with their move set.

I think the thing I love the most about this game is the concept. I've had to improvise my combos in game to see what works and what doesn't and the difficutly is pretty high - especialy on Nightmare mode. I guess I'm one of those players that love a challenge and when I get beaten I keep coming back for more.

The online multiplayer is pretty buggy at the moment so don't rely on that. I understand they are working on it, but as of now - it's plagued with problems. If you have a friend/child you can play with then there is still lots of fun to be had, especially with the 4 player vs mode. And if you can trust them to not throw fireballs into your back, turn friendly fire on and play like a pro.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Going to be pretty brief on this review, so it'll be in sections.

Artwise: Abyss Odyssey is... well. Lovely to look at. I don't think anyone expected anything else. Though rather then the Fantasy-Punk vibe of Zeno Clash it is instead something of an Art Nouveau fever dream. Its distinctly late 19th century Chilean, and honestly that makes it feel almost as unique as ZenoClash. Simply because of the lack of well, games with that vibe.

The Fighting: It is not bad. It is also not that great. It reminds me heavily of the old Squeenix brawlers like The Bouncer or Ergheiz (especially the adventure mode) The primary point that needs to be understood is you absolutely must cancel animations in a careful pattern to actually make combos.  There are moves with a certain number of hits, but chaining together moves and quickly dispatching enemies, or preventing yourself from being torn apart requires a different skillset then most fighting games do. It's kind of like Orb Walking in a MOBA. I enjoy it greatly, but I think it should be called a 'side-scrolling combo-brawler' over a 'fighting game'. The only flaw I see is it takes some getting used to to figure out how not to get stuck in animations, and some things feel unresponsive. (Turning isn't as bad as people say it is, but it COULD use some work. I imagine it'll be tweaked in the future.  I also have a feelong allot of the extremely negative reviews are from earlier builds as right now, it's quick.)

The story: Small, compact, folklore rich and not particularly invasive. Its not some mesmerising story with a gripping narrative, but its a functional fairy-tale that conveys a rich and enthralling world. It takes multiple trips into the abyss to actually tell its tale.

The Monster-Capture-thing: Gonna be honest, I am sad. SAD I SAY. I reeeaaaaally am a sucker for cute monsters, and would love to just be able to choose them at the start of the game after catching them. However, despite people's reviews, they're more then a damage sponge (an alternate pool of hitpoints, really) While they can serve that purpose, they've got interesting movesets with specific advantages. Some of these can be used to cheaply deal with certain enemies. (The mimic can absolutely trash a few for instance) While others are more all around useful and versatile or even allow better terrain navigation. (Pudutaur is incredibly mobile and has fantastic range on her melee)

Finally. Pudu-Taur. Seriously. Pudutaur. That enough should sell the game. Don't know what a pudu is? Look it up. Pudutaur.

Pudutaur.

reviewText:
First things first, this game is beautifully crafted. It is certainly one of the most visually appealing games I have played. I am typically not a fan of this style of metroidvania inspired game. Primarily because I am simply not very good at them and they become frustrating rather than fun fairly quickly.

With this game I find that the story and visual appeal continue to draw me in. Even though I am not very good at the game, I continue to come back to it because I am curious to see what will happen next and what new environments will be revealed as I slowly progress into the abyss.

I highly recommend this game. For those who like me, are not very adept at platforming hack and slash games a patient approach is well rewarded. For fans of metroid and castlevania, you do not want to miss this game. It is a stunning and amazingly deep experience.

reviewText:
Partial Nudity? Oh, hells yeah.

Well, I haven't seen any of that yet, but Abyss Odyssey is still a damn fine game. The aesthetic is excellent, sucks you right in. The character designs are well thought out, and everything about them and the environment is pretty. What dialogue the game has is minimal, but that's all that's needed to tell the story.

Basically, a Warlock has been sleeping for Christ knows how many years, and his nightmares are leaking into the real world, manifesting as real threats. You can choose from three different characters, but you only start with one, Katrien.  They can be played as interchangably throughout the game.

The game is difficult! There's an optional nightmare mode, which I haven't touched yet, but the default difficulties are either easy, moderate, and hard, and vary depending on which level of the abyss you're in. The easy levels are a tad challenging, but nothing terrible. The hard levels have threats around every corner, and you'll be lucky if you have 1/4 of the health you went into them with by the time you reach the exit.

The controls are fine tuned, as they should be for an action platformer like this. They are strange at first, and might feel wonky, but as you play you pick up how it works. You really feel like it's your fault when you're hit by an enemy, and not the fault of the controls.

I haven't made it very far in this game, maybe four levels down (which isn't far). But it's definitely worth picking up if you like what you see in the videos. It's a unique experience, I've never quite played a game like it before. And for $15 it's worth it.

reviewText:
What do you say about this game? I could tell you that the art style is gorgeous, evoking equal parts the saturated fantastical gloss of Trine and dreamworld fantasy with beautiful, clean Art Noveau.
I could tell you that, mechanically, it's Smash Bros. meets a Roguelite.
I could also tell you that there are technical flaws which harm the game in many ways, that the game is mostly balanced for playing alone and thus making the co-op modes nearly superfluous, not even counting the great technical flaws in the online co-op.

In the end I will say that it is possible to get used to the technical flaws and that there is a great charm in playing what is essentially Smash Bros. with a stamina-based cancelling mechanic in a simple, Roguelite map with fantastic art and presentation. It starts out hard, but gets easier as you get used to the mechanics. If it still doesn't feel quite there, try disabling the V-sync in the options; for some reason, this helps the responsiveness even with a gamepad.

reviewText:
Abyss Odyssey has been a very mixed experience for me.  The art style is gorgeous and the sound track is solid.  The voice acting is pretty good with some well known names and the overall design and aesthetic of the world is very interesting and focuses on mythology seldom seen in other games.

Then there's the combat.  Others may be able to enjoy it, but I have had so many issues with the stiff, frequently unresponsive controls.  The enemy AI is at times deceptively cheap and evil and also at times very thick, with enemies patiently waiting for me to get done with their buddy ten feet away before coming at me.  Maybe this has to do with the controls being based on fighting games, but it feels like a poor man's super smash brothers and the character's movesets are remarkably shallow.

It helps that you can capture and play as almost all the enemies in the game, but their moves are similarly shallow.

I enjoyed this game for a bit, but it requires many play throughs.  I haven't finished them all and I'm not sure I will.  It's worth playing for the experience, but overall, it could have been better.  You can easily beat the game, probably in less than 3-4 hours, but it does ask for many play throughs so...bear that in mind.  That's a lot of investment for some generally clunky combat.

reviewText:
This game is actually quite good. I'm impressed with how many techniques they were able to take from fighting games, and the execution of them inside a platformer Roguelike is doubly impressive. The game is set up similar to a roguelike dungeon crawl-- go in, fight your way to the bottom, fighting a few bosses along the way, and defeating a final boss. But what makes it so good is the depth of the mechanics, and how they work together-- You may choose from three basic characters, yet there are many more available. To get them, you have to defeat them with a super and then you can pick up their soul-- and thus, you are now playing as a fully featured character whenever you want to transform. While you can only carry one soul at a time, it gives a much deeper mechanic to the game: Should you opt for a monster early on to help you along, or save the super to get one you really want later? It takes quite some time to fill up the mana meter, so the choice is important, as it gives you a whole life bar to survive longer. Each enemy plays completely differently, but gives a great deal depth as a result.

One thing that should be mentioned is that the game might feel somewhat slow and a bit clunky at first. I feel this is actually a good thing, though, as it leaves the player able to improve and attack much faster than is initially able, giving a real sense of progression in an intuitive way. This ties into progressing: If you're not good enough to defeat the enemies, you won't reach the end.

Speaking of the enemies, they are NPC opponents, which inevitably means they're 'not perfect'. That is to say, they're sometimes too perfect and too good at reading what you're going to do. I'd love to see more work made to improve on enemy AI as the game's life progresses, but this is my only real gripe, and it's not even a big one. The enemies are certainly able to be defeated, it's more of a survival gauntlet than anything, but sometimes they adjust their behaviours a little too fast when you input something.

All in all, an extremely enjoyable game, which I hope will have a fruitful life and a large community. The quality is astounding for the price of the game; puts many AAA games to shame.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
QUICK REVIEW:
+Wierd art style
+Fun RPG mechanics
+Interesting setting/characters
-iffy controls
Not sure what's up with all the negative reviews on this one
Anyway, this is basically a metroidvania with an actual combat system instead of basic attacks seen in most similar games.
ACE tried to capture the feel of a fighting game with the combat, as can be seen in the fact that literally every character/enemy in the game is playable in one way or another. All and all it feels out of place at first, but it's easy enough to get used to. Speaking of characters, the design of this game is unlike anything I've seen before; many of the monsters the player encounters are very interesting to look at, and often have eerie glowing or melting effects to them. This entire game really looks strange, yet at the same time great.
Other than that this is just an RPG rougelite where dying sends you back to the start without your equipment, but leveling and cash stay with you after death. I'm not the biggest fan of procedurally-generated enviroments, but the dungeon this game takes place in is varied enough to keep my attention.

In the end I have to say that this really is a good game. My only real complaint is that attack inputs often feel wonky or unresponsive since you're probably not going to learn the attacks of all the characters you play as.


Also a lot of people are complaining about co-op and KB/M controls.
Dunno anything about these; I've been playing this game alone with a 360 controller

reviewText:
This one's a difficult one for me as to whether I'd recommend it or not.

It's a Metroidvania style game with a complex combat system full of melee strikes, special attacks, a grab, blocking, counters, move cancels and combos. You know the saying 'easy to learn, hard to master'? Well, the combat is this game isn't easy to learn. It's almost as if you're trying to play the more recent Street Fighter games in a platformer on the highest difficulty possible.

There's three main characters and each has a soldier that jumps in when they die, basically like a second life. If you can get to an altar the main character resurrects and you continue on with them. The soldiers have similar combat styles as their corresponding main character but have different melee and special moves. Then you can absorb the soul of nearly any enemy in the game, even the bosses apparently, and fight as them. Each of them also has their own melee and special moves.

Enemies seem to be reasonably varied, though three specific ones will be seen often the entire way through the game. As I said above, they all have their own attacks which they all like to use to stunlock and air juggle you until you die.

So, can I recommend this? I'm not sure. If you like Metroidvania style games and can deal with the complexities of the combat here, then yes. If not you may want to give this one a pass. Based upon my own experience and feelings, I have to lean slightly more towards the 'no' side.

reviewText:
I wanted to like Abyss Odyssey.  The combination of fighting games and roguelike elements has been under-represented since the PS1 era. (Hi, Tobal 2's Quest mode.)  Controls that draw from Smash Bros should have meant a maneuverable adventure game, something that should have had little difficulty surpassing Brawl's underwhelming Subspace Emissary mode.

Unfortunately, that is not the game that ACE Team delivered.  I've waited quite a while to see if the game would change before posting my review, but I haven't seen evidence that my opinion will change.

Combat simply feels off, as if it is sluggish or clunky.  Jumping feels floaty and forced.  Aerial moves do not mesh well with jumping.  While the control scheme in its most basic form is designed around the control scheme of Smash Bros, the actual mechanics and maneuverability (and lack thereof) are not.  The game relies on a cancel point system for combos, where you can cancel only if you have a 'cancel orb' available.  Cancel orbs are so important and integral to combat that you should spend your first levels unlocking them instead of upgrading moves, which begs the question of why they weren't unlocked from the start.  People will point to YouTube videos of various combos as examples of how amazing the combo system is, but those combos are almost always impractical within the single-player game itself.

'Replay' consists in no small part of an unlock system that is designed to be a grind-driven time sink.  You cannot just encounter an enemy and defeat it to 'capture' it.  You have to have a full magic bar, and land a killing blow with a special capture move (that drains the bar regardless of success).  If it ended there, it might be acceptable, but the game goes further.  You have to be at a minimum level to capture an enemy, and the required level is heavily artificially inflated compared to the difficulty of the opponent.  The only solution is to grind your level through repeated plays of the same character.  It doesn't  matter that you can beat every enemy in the game when in your low teens for level.  The game will simply not let you capture various enemies until you are level 30, 40 or even 60, even if you have been beating that enemy without issue from the time that your level was a single digit value.

As for level design, Abyss Odyssey unfortunately functions as an example of the shortcomings of relying on procedural generation.  The component parts that the system has to rely upon simply aren't interesting, nor are the final results.

All in all, to some degree I feel a bit sorry for ACE Team.  They obviously tried, but their ambitions may simply have been beyond their abilities and business realities.  (A budget title with fighting game movesets and animations for all player characters and enemies?)

Do I recommend the game? At full price, I find that I cannot.  However, if you do find the concept interesting, and find others say enough positive things, then perhaps consider buying it when it is at a good sale price.  At worst, you might find a disappointing title.  At best, you might find it a hidden gem that you will continue to play.  I, unfortunately, fell into the former category.  Others have obviously fallen into the latter.

reviewText:
First things first, this game is beautifully crafted. It is certainly one of the most visually appealing games I have played. I am typically not a fan of this style of metroidvania inspired game. Primarily because I am simply not very good at them and they become frustrating rather than fun fairly quickly.

With this game I find that the story and visual appeal continue to draw me in. Even though I am not very good at the game, I continue to come back to it because I am curious to see what will happen next and what new environments will be revealed as I slowly progress into the abyss.

I highly recommend this game. For those who like me, are not very adept at platforming hack and slash games a patient approach is well rewarded. For fans of metroid and castlevania, you do not want to miss this game. It is a stunning and amazingly deep experience.

reviewText:
First thoughts: Street Fighter combat meets classical Art Nouveu. Finely drawn stills with clumsy polygonal animation and stunted voice acting. Welcome to a rogue-lite adventure where the combat may drive you mad, or be your cup of tea. A well planned introduction that is going to steep you in combat mechanics you either have the reflexes for or are willing to practice to obtain.

Having never been competent at fighting games (I beat Street Fighter II on the SNES but once at difficulty 'III'), I admit I'm in over my head and instantly grateful for the weapon and moveset upgrading system. If I've any chance at all, that alone is to be thanked.

This is a lucious game, and there's a lot to love, if you're a genre fan. Awkward voiceovers can be overlooked, the base character leveling system gives less skilled players a chance. Unfortunately the character animations are quite stilted and lack the polish that would have better integrated them into the classic, 1890s art style.

For an indie, this is an impressive start but for full price this is too much to ask for casual players. This is no minor distraction, but a lore rich, gorgeously presented nightmare. Know your quarry before spending your coin.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Pros:
+ The Music
+ Most of the Art Style (especially character representations in dialog)
+ Multiple Paths to the End of the Game (akin to FTL)
+ Concept of who/what the starting protagonist is

Cons:
- Rigid movement/combat
- Set up so you can get stun-locked (juggled in the air by multiple enemies
- You lose your weapons and items when you die, and get one chance to get them back with inferior gear (a la Diablo 1), or they're gone for good
- No sense of empowerment when you level up or do get a skill bonus
- Combat often feels luck-based (concerning if an enemy will block or dodge or not)
- Die twice without reaching a checkpoint and you start over at the beginning of the abyss (dungeon) again
- Very little story unless you read journal fragments from the menu, and they seem randomly obtained out of order
- Skills/abilities are outclassed by most other 2D side-scroller type games
- Game length appears to be short but stretched out by having to start over repeatedly without a real sense of growth

Summary:
This game has some nice qualities to it, but there are far too many negatives for me to recommend it. Although I'm not into Dark Souls, I've played it a bit, and that game at least gives you some serious power if you're careful and level up a few times. You get to keep your equipment and only lose the XP (souls) you hadn't spent yet if you die twice. In Abyss Odyssey, however, there's just a feeling of no progress at all. Honestly, I would recommend Rogue Legacy if you want a 2D roguelite experience that does it right. Check out folks' reviews for Rogue Legacy if you haven't tried it before but like the idea of a difficult but fair game with gradual growth even when you lose and start over. I'm a wuss, and even I dig that game.

reviewText:
Would like to preface this by saying I could see this being enjoyable for people into this kind of game but it just wasn't for me.

Pros:
I really enjoy the art style of this game.
Atmosphere is nice as well the rooms can change pretty drastically.
Interesting set up with dungeon rooms varying in difficulty, it lets you take a quick way down through alot of hard rooms or plan a longer way that may hit easy/medium rooms more often.
The soul collection for an extra life and skill set is a neat mechanic.

Cons:
Repeatative in every way, aside from collecting souls there are only 3 characters and the soldiers you become when you die. The game is basically running the same yet different (Randomly rearranged) dungeon over and over.
The leveling is pointless really, it's simply a gate on which souls you can capture.
Really doesn't feel like there's much of an end goal to it, since winning just lets you start again and dying starts you again. I haven't managed to win yet but I'd assume you'd get to keep your weapons in that case. Losing your weapons on death makes sense for some difficulty but also ruins any feeling of progression you achieved.
Ranged attacks are almost useless since the AI is godly at dodging them, they can be used to bait them in but rarely for damage, in my noob opinion.


Ultimately I bought the game for it's style which I still enjoy but the game just isn't enjoyable enough for me to play that much. But if you're curious I'd suggest watching some gameplay videos to see how it looks to you.

reviewText:
Abyss Odyssey is a beautiful game with a nice gameplay and combat mechanics. It focus on the Hero/Soldier duality, when the Hero dies then a Soldier comes to continue it's progress. You have a chance to revive the Hero at an Altar if you make it that far. The Soldiers are weaker but still capable on their own and provide an interesting gameplay ideia: you're forced to do with the Soldiers what you could not do with the Hero.

The art style is incredible, all characters including enemies are very well design and the environments fit well within the game. The combat is varied and allows you to choose between 3 Heros + 3 Soldiers + about 20 different monsters you can summon once in a while. Each one has its own style and unique special abilities.

The game is a bit difficult, to get to the final boss you have to pass through many levels with different difficulties and if both your Hero and Soldier dies you're back to square one. There are checkpoints along the way to save progress but these require tokens which are quite expensive. Any attempt to defeat the final boss is an expedition that requires preparation and nerves of steel.

Pros:
- Amazing art style
- 3 heros to choose + a bunch of other playable characters
- Good combat
- Random generated levels improve replayability
- Made by the Zeno-Clash boys, guaranteed seal of Awesomeness

Cons:
- Controls are a bit slugish
- Better to play with Xbox controller
- Being bum-rushed to death happens from time to time
- Random generated levels end up being repetitive
- Difficulty

reviewText: I reviewed this game for DieHard GameFAN. This is the short attention span summary of my review: Abyss Odyssey combines a myriad of genres to provide a unique experience that might not be to everyone’s taste. The platforming is wonky, the combat takes some adjusting, and the game is ruthless in its challenge. Enemies will react to your every move and pay you back in kind, plus the randomness of the dungeon layouts can work both for or against you and involve a lot of luck. Still, if you’re a fan of all of the genres represented here and can handle the steep difficulty, you’ll likely have a good time. Especially if you have a friend available to play along with you.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Abyss Odyssey is procedurally generated, side scrolling Beat 'em up. The player is tasked with venturing deep into the procedurally generated abyss with the goal of killing a warlock. In order to accomplish their goal, the player must learn the secrets of the abyss through trial and error. failure is common.

Throughout the abyss, the player will battle a multitude of dangerous creatures through melee combat. This combat feels sluggish and stiff initially. Later on however, it becomes much more enjoyable as the player masters the combat system and unlocks more moves. As a result Abyss Odyssey runs the risk of turning new players away before it gets interesting. Players who persevere are rewarded as they learn how best to combo moves and abilities together effectively, yet even in it's later stages, it lacks some of the polish found in other side scrolling Beat 'em ups. I found that using a controller helped a bit with some of the combat's issues, as the game was clearly designed with a gamepad in mind. Altogether the combat is decent, but not great. Little things like not being able to change directions in the middle of a combo and poor aerial combat drag the experience down. Where Abyss Odyssey's combat makes up for it's lack of polish is in variety. The number of playable characters is surprisingly impressive, and while many are not as developed as others, they still help change up the combat occasionally.

I was also pleasantly surprised by Abyss Odyssey's procedurally generated level design. While nothing groundbreaking, the levels it generates feel well constructed and reasonably different. While they still lack the same tightly focused nature of many hand-made levels, they serve as a good backdrop for the game's combat, even mixing in a bit of light platforming to break things up. Throughout these levels Abyss Odyssey offers the player many opportunities to make risk reward based choices which leverage immediate reward against the risk of long term peril. While a nice system, I rarely found any situations where the risks outweighed the benefits, effectively undermining the tension these systems could have created if they were more effectively balanced.

Abyss Odyssey's most notable feature is its art and music. The environments on display are beautiful to look at and manage to help disguise the procedural generation. Character designs are especially good. Each one is reasonably interesting to look at. As a result, I always enjoyed seeing what creature I would stumble upon next. Abyss Odyssey's soundtrack is also fairly good, and manages to capture the mood of the game just right. I especially liked the eerie guitar pieces, which add to the unique atmosphere.

Despite it's numerous flaws, I still believe I can give Abyss Odyssey a cautious recommendation. Anyone interested in a procedurally generated Beat 'em up will likely be satisfied, so long as they can overlook some frustrating design elements.
