reviewText:
QUICK REVIEW:
+Wierd art style
+Fun RPG mechanics
+Interesting setting/characters
-iffy controls
Not sure what's up with all the negative reviews on this one
Anyway, this is basically a metroidvania with an actual combat system instead of basic attacks seen in most similar games.
ACE tried to capture the feel of a fighting game with the combat, as can be seen in the fact that literally every character/enemy in the game is playable in one way or another. All and all it feels out of place at first, but it's easy enough to get used to. Speaking of characters, the design of this game is unlike anything I've seen before; many of the monsters the player encounters are very interesting to look at, and often have eerie glowing or melting effects to them. This entire game really looks strange, yet at the same time great.
Other than that this is just an RPG rougelite where dying sends you back to the start without your equipment, but leveling and cash stay with you after death. I'm not the biggest fan of procedurally-generated enviroments, but the dungeon this game takes place in is varied enough to keep my attention.

In the end I have to say that this really is a good game. My only real complaint is that attack inputs often feel wonky or unresponsive since you're probably not going to learn the attacks of all the characters you play as.


Also a lot of people are complaining about co-op and KB/M controls.
Dunno anything about these; I've been playing this game alone with a 360 controller

reviewText:
I've played this game for a few hours during the free weekend and it's pretty addictive, mainly because of its rogue-like elements, leveling up your character and diving further and further into the abyss.

Pros:
+ I really like the art style. Characters are unique and pretty weird. Great atmosphere in every level; it feels a bit like Trine.
+ You can morph into the enemies you've slain! That's really cool.
+ The RPG elements are pretty well done, although I'm not too sure about the skill points. As in every good rogue-like dying really matters and resources are limited.

Cons:
- Abyss Odyssey feels like a mixture of Rogue Legacy and Super Smash Brothers, but the controls are clunkier than both of those games (and that's not really a good thing).
- It's hard to time attacks, especially since most enemies instantly block. But maybe I'm just a noob at this game.
- Unsure about the replay value. There are quite a few unlockable characters, but I doubt the game is entertaining enough to do multiple runs.

I wouldn't pay the full price, but I recommend picking up this game on sale (currently 3 euros). I still want to try out local coop.

reviewText:
I was pleasantly surprised by this game.

All the reasons that you checked out this game in the first place are reasons to buy this game.  Rogue-lite with great art direction and a moody atmosphere.  The controls take a little getting used to (DISCLAIMER: I have only used a mouse/keyboard at this point), but the combat is fun and engaging.  Learn to read your enemies attacks, balance dodges with blocks and wait for the right moment to counter-attack.

Do yourself a favor and play with a friend, voice-chat enabled, with friendly fire turned on.  You will die, and you will kill each other, but you will learn and you will like it.

reviewText: Quite Fun But Very Challenging!\n\nJust tried this game out on a whim and it is actually quite fun.  Surprisingly it is a 2d random map sidescroller that plays quite a bit like super smash brothers!  As a fighting game fan I actually notice quite a few things you normally don't need to worry about in games EXCEPT for a fighting game (Armor, cancelling, frames etc.)  I have logged 9 hours so far but am still really liking it.  Something kind of trippy about venturing into the encarnation of a mad warlock's dreams and the whole game feels surreal.  I would recommend it but be patient.  The game is quite difficult and takes some studying to be effective.  Even once you get it you will still have some hard times decending into the depths.

I defintely reccommend this game on sale. It's a game full of potential. It lacks a bit of variety and the pacing throws you off the deep end and expects you to get good.

The game very much expects you to master cancels and doesn't really teach you how.

Having said that, the controls are very responsive and appropriately punishing. The combat has weight to it, and that crazy lunge will either be the coup de grace or your ultimate undoing.

I'd love to see these devs come back and ditch the rogue-like for a fleshed out game with pacing. The next Guacamelee could come from this team.

reviewText:
ACE Team are keen on creating memorable, talked-about games, and their latest creation, Abyss Odyssey, will do just that. In a blend of Metroidvania-esque levels, rogue-like gameplay and setup, and Chilean-inspired themes, settings, and design Abyss Odyssey will test your patience. But like the Souls franchise, you will keep coming back for more and more punishment. Why? Because you will never let a game get the better of you, and as a gamer, you have to see those credits roll. Okay, perhaps Abyss Odyssey isn’t that hardcore, but you get the idea. ACE Team has recaptured an idea that has worked for 20+ years with series like Mega Man, Castlevania, and Metroid. And while it’s not a complete overhaul of the genre, it’s a step in the right direction for the side-scrolling dungeon crawler genre.

Everyone’s game will start the same: you’ll control Katrien, whose Rapier will allow you to make considerable progress through the procedurally generated dungeons on your way to tackle the Warlock in the Abyss. I say considerable due to the fact that it’s unlikely you’ll make it too far before Katrien is defeated and you must then, as a weak soldier, return to a nearby resurrection altar and return her to life, or start over from the beginning. Not all is lost if you die though, as your solider ‘spirit’ (so to speak) isn’t completely useless, but he’s a much weaker competitor than you yourself. Katrien (and your soldier companion) has a bevy of attacks and special moves to accompany you in your journey ranging from arching swipes, to fireballs, and sliding attacks. Utilized in conjunction with one another makes her a satisfying warrior, but the no-so-tight controls and platforming leads level exploration a lot to be desired.

Platforming games have been around for decades, and they aren’t going anywhere, and when I get my hands on one, I’m personally spoiled by them. Having played every Mario game to death, Nintendo has perfected platforming; and with 2D Castlevania and Metroid games helping cement how graceful platformers can be, playing a game that’s a step back is really frustrating. Abyss Odyssey’s isn’t the worst of the genre, but it’s not up there with the best either. Most of the time, you can double jump then dash over crevices, but occasionally you come upon the dreaded ‘ledge’ wherein it’s 90% impossible to overcome unless you’re facing the right direction. Turning to get in the right direction is a bit of a delay, this making even the simplest of things, such as turning your character(s), rather cumbersome. Yes, this sounds almost elementary, but when you’re trying to hurriedly get somewhere and you’re halted in climbing due to such a minor inconvenience, it’s immensely frustrating. Again, it’s not ‘bad’, but it’s unsatisfying when it happens more often than it should.

Another issue with Abyss Odyssey is its lack of real direction in terms of explaining what you can and cannot do. For example, when your mana meter builds, you’re able to unleash an attack that not only deals damage, but allows you to capture the soul of your foe. You’re then able to freely switch between the soul of your newly acquired demon, each with their own set of attacks and moves, to help in the journey. Unfortunately, none if this is really implied or explained. ACE Team has created a world I want to explore, but provides no understanding of the rules or regulations. As far as plot goes (another lacking feature as far as its delivery) comes in the form of pages of the Warlock’s journal that randomly drop from vanquished adversaries. The twenty page journal tells you everything about the Warlock’s beginning, middle, and end, but not much else aside from small bits about the creatures in the Abyss. I’m all for subtlety and minimalism, but at some point explanation and direction is needed, and Abyss Odyssey loses on that front.

What’s found in Abyss Odyssey is a solid exploratory platformer with minor aggravations, but with rich design marred by poor direction and exposition. You will spend hours upon hours collecting enemies, hunting through the various dungeons, and defeating the famed Warlock; and then come back for more. With multiple playable characters, each with their own distinctive characteristics and attacks, there’s enough content to provide second and third playthroughs. And while we were unable to test this while playing pre-embargo, ACE Team promises a ton of continuous changes and additions to the game as more and more people complete the task of defeating the Warlock. Abyss Odyssey holds a world of fun in itself. In the end though, it’s just a shame that what’s here, although it isn’t genre-changing, isn’t enough to pull it from the depths of a dozen of other lookalikes. There’s a bevy of treasures to discover in the great below, however, so don’t pass up the chance to explore it. When Abyss Odyssey stares in to you, smirk and say ‘let’s go’!

(Review via Front Towards Gamer: http://ftg.operationsupplydrop.org/2015/02/09/hyperdimension-neptunia-rebirth-1-review-pc/)

reviewText:
EDITED TO REFLECT CHANGING CIRCUMSTANCES
--
After finally (with no help from any of the forums) sorting our my controller to work with this game, I am now able to play it, so I thought I'd do the right thing and change my review.

The game is actually really cool. At first the controls feel clunky but once you get a handle of things, it works out. The graphics, voice acting, aesthetics and overall atmosphere is wonderful and engaging, and the mechanic of controlling lesser creatures is pretty cool too, though it may take a while before you get there. The gameplay is also pretty cool, and it's fun leveling up a character and unleashing fun combos on enemies. Training mode is your friend. The rogue-like elements are also well-balanced; you keep all gold but lose items/weapons, so you actually progress further down the cave each time, but it's still difficult, and you may still lose on the first segment.

However, changing directions in this game is clunky at times, unlike the rest of the controls. It feels like wading through gelatin. I'd recommend it on sale, or if you like rogue-likes. Maybe also if you like Trine. But otherwise, try playing another RPG, rogue-like, or maybe even a fighting game.


Original Review:
Don't let the 'Full Controller Support' thing fool you - PS3 and PS4 controllers are NOT supported and the developers don't care. And playing with a keyboard is an awful experience; akin to playing Mortal Kombat or some other fighting game using just a mouse.

reviewText:
Genre: Fighting-Rougelike
Overall rating: 86%
Gameplay: 17/20
Sound/Music: 9/10
Graphics: 4/5 - Art design: 5/5
Controls: 3/5
Replay value: 5/5

Gameplay;
It's a fighting/platformer game with rouge-like elements. Combat works just like in a fighting game, every character/enemy has a proper move set, but instead of just a one screen arena, you have to fight through a randomized dungeon with multiple floors and paths.
The game has around 40 characters, three of them are main characters with the ability to capture enemy souls. This is one of the key features of the game, because once you capture a soul you can use that enemy/boss in the game. There are some ballance issues with this though, some are near worthless some are op and this can impact versus mode.
However it's not just a regular figthing game with platforming. The game has co-op and an inventory system, your main charactes can level up and gain skill points to strengthen moves they have found.

Sound/Music;
Music is excellent, sometimes reminds me of Castlevania, it creates a good atmosphere for the levels and characters. But it doesn't have any God tier" songs that I would put on my mp3 player so it's "just" a 9 out of 10.

Graphics;
Nothing extraordinary here

reviewText:
Abyss Odyssey
Rating 7/10
Overview: Unique 2D roque-lite

The Good:

+ Unique art style

+ Very creative enemy design. It is always refreshing to play a game that has interesting characters

+ One of the main aspects of the game is that you can collect enemy spirits by filling up your mana bar and then unleashing a devastating area of effect attack. Once you collect an enemy spirit you can then transform into that enemy and play as them. The game has quite a few enemies so capturing and trying out all the different enemies is fun. The only stipulation is that you have to be the same level or higher in order to capture an enemy.

+ The game has 3 main playable characters. You start with one but unlock the other 2 through different means. Each character has their own weapons, attacks and special attacks.

+ As you level up you gain skill points to upgrade your special attacks. You can either make them do more damage, get more mana or provide you with defensive abilities.

+ Soundtrack

The Average:

Given the unique art style, the level design is comparatively bland. This is a 2D roque game so each level is randomized. Although each level is designed differently in some way, every level feels the same. I find games like Spelunky and  even Risk of Rain to be good examples of randomization done right. The levels in those games truly feel different, hazardous and unique as you progress through the levels. Making it through those levels feels like an accomplishment, this game does not. Although there are plenty of environmental hazards to avoid the game is more about combat than navigating the levels.

You will either love or hate the combat. The combat IS good IF you take to the time to master it. The combat is a bit reminiscent of a 2D fighting game and it comes with some pretty advanced techniques to learn if you truly want to get the most out of it. The majority of players will probably just keep spamming their favorite special attacks over and over again.


Gold is useless. When you die you lose all currently equipped items which makes sense given the fact it's a rogue game however you get to retain your gold and experience making subsequent runs through the abyss easier. Many of the items the shopkeepers sell is usually over priced and since you lose your equipment anyways, buying any equipment feels somewhat pointless


Conclusion

It certainly is a very unique game something that I would expect from the developers of Zeno Clash. The combat is good and trying out all the different enemies is awesome the problem is everything else that makes a roque game good is average in this game.  This game certainly has potential to be a great game and a sequel that fleshes out some of the ideas would really help.

reviewText:
I've seen a lot of negative feedback about the controls in this game.  True, there was a moment or two in the beginning where I almost swung my controller at my monitor like a chromed up War Boy with a mace.  But a few things happened that allowed me to beat the game after a few hours of play.

1) I somehow stumbled upon the monk character.  Everything is better once you get that cloaked, knee-padded savior.  I also liked Pincoya (the other unlockable character) and her spear.

2) I read up a bit about the game and learned about Cancel points.  Invest your level up points in those before anything else.

3) It turns out that button mashing is still relevant in fighting (style) games.  But to be fair, it's mostly parry mashing in this game.  You still need to learn the controls.

10/10 would roll the controller against their forehead if it meant beating a horde of enemies.

reviewText:
If you don't like games with a challenge, and if games such as Dark Souls make you whimper in a corner and cry, Abyss Odyssey is not a game for you.

In this game, you need to learn the controls. You need to learn how the enemies fight and you need to build and adjust your characters skills and special attacks in order to progress.

Some have described Abyss Odyssey as a mix of Super Smash Bros. Brawl and Castlevania? That comparision is only partly correct: the gameplay reminds me a bit of Super Smash Bros Brawl, but not Castlevania. Unlike in Castlevania, in this game, you cannot just whip&One-Shot-Kill basic enemies. A mob of low-level enemies can easily hack'n slash you into pieces, if you are not careful. Health vials are scarse, mana-vials are even more rare and good weapons cost a lot of coins. Did I mention there are no free save-points? In order to save progress, you need to grind enough coins, then you need to find a merchant who sells a camp token, and then you need to find an altar to use a camp token to have one or maybe two retries from that particular point.

The game graphics are sounds are awesome, but I am personally more attracted by the fair challenge of this game. The game is quite merciful to some degree: for example, dying does not automatically reset your character experience and it does not strip you from your special attacks you built, only your weapons and items are lost, and you are returned to one of the three starting stages.

I'd say learning to use different attacks and gradually proceeding in this game is the main hook, so for skill-oriented players looking for a bit of a challenge in a game, this is one to pick. The game is also very beautiful, has unique and interesting lore and is flawlessly designed.

I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

All the reasons that you checked out this game in the first place are reasons to buy this game.  Rogue-lite with great art direction and a moody atmosphere. Do yourself a favor and play with a friend, voice-chat enabled, with friendly fire turned on.  You will die, and you will kill each other, but you will learn and you will like it.

reviewText:
Abyss Odyssey is procedurally generated, side scrolling Beat 'em up. The player is tasked with venturing deep into the procedurally generated abyss with the goal of killing a warlock. In order to accomplish their goal, the player must learn the secrets of the abyss through trial and error. failure is common.

Throughout the abyss, the player will battle a multitude of dangerous creatures through melee combat. This combat feels sluggish and stiff initially. Later on however, it becomes much more enjoyable as the player masters the combat system and unlocks more moves. As a result Abyss Odyssey runs the risk of turning new players away before it gets interesting. Players who persevere are rewarded as they learn how best to combo moves and abilities together effectively, yet even in it's later stages, it lacks some of the polish found in other side scrolling Beat 'em ups. I found that using a controller helped a bit with some of the combat's issues, as the game was clearly designed with a gamepad in mind. Altogether the combat is decent, but not great. Little things like not being able to change directions in the middle of a combo and poor aerial combat drag the experience down. Where Abyss Odyssey's combat makes up for it's lack of polish is in variety. The number of playable characters is surprisingly impressive, and while many are not as developed as others, they still help change up the combat occasionally.

I was also pleasantly surprised by Abyss Odyssey's procedurally generated level design. While nothing groundbreaking, the levels it generates feel well constructed and reasonably different. While they still lack the same tightly focused nature of many hand-made levels, they serve as a good backdrop for the game's combat, even mixing in a bit of light platforming to break things up. Throughout these levels Abyss Odyssey offers the player many opportunities to make risk reward based choices which leverage immediate reward against the risk of long term peril. While a nice system, I rarely found any situations where the risks outweighed the benefits, effectively undermining the tension these systems could have created if they were more effectively balanced.

Abyss Odyssey's most notable feature is its art and music. The environments on display are beautiful to look at and manage to help disguise the procedural generation. Character designs are especially good. Each one is reasonably interesting to look at. As a result, I always enjoyed seeing what creature I would stumble upon next. Abyss Odyssey's soundtrack is also fairly good, and manages to capture the mood of the game just right. I especially liked the eerie guitar pieces, which add to the unique atmosphere.

Despite it's numerous flaws, I still believe I can give Abyss Odyssey a cautious recommendation. Anyone interested in a procedurally generated Beat 'em up will likely be satisfied, so long as they can overlook some frustrating design elements.

reviewText:
Abyss Odyssey is a platform based fighting game with a bit of story, a randomized map, and a whole lot of crazy. A major facet of the game is that death is not the end; not necessarily even in each playthough. When the main character, one of either Katrien, a dead dude with hands but no body, or a sea goddess, dies, they are simply replaced by a soldier (still playable, of course) who can revive the main at certain alters. Only when the soldier dies must you restart. However, death only costs you your progress down and your current one items. Level, exp, and gold are kept.
This game has a special mechanic that adds one more layer in. The main can use a special skill and rip the soul from an enemy, gaining the ability to transform into any enemy, including all bosses. Dying as a monster turns you back to the main, adding another layer of life. Which you will need because the monsters are brutally unmercifully good at beating you to a pulp. The AI is intelligent and each monster knows its strengths. If a monster is fast but weak and you shield, it'll wait for a hard hitter to show up and they will tag-team you to death.
The story (for characters, primarily. There isnt much of a plot.) and art of the game are amazing. The story is that a powerful warlock is in a asleep in a coma or something, and his nightmares are materializing in the real world. As one of his dreams, you are trying to stop him. Characters and monster are primarily from old Chilean myth and folklore and also a considerable amount from the Christian bible, plus many from various other worldwide myths, all with the wonderful wackiness of ACE. Plus there is also a crossover character from Zeno Clash now.


Pros:
Great visuals, music and designs.
Every character/enemy is playable.

Either way:
Difficulty. The game is brutal. There is no easy mode or tutorial. Only hard or harder. I like that, but not everyone does.
Enemies are really smart and know you, so you have to know and exploit them. Finding ways to successfully spam attacks is generally rewarded with not dying. You can do it, but so can the enemies, so it could go either way.
Animation cancelling is a major mechanic. This means that learning combos through hard trial and error is the best way and messing one up can mean a lost battle due to long animations. The mechanic is really cool though, so again, either way.

Cons:
Controls can be a tad floaty, but its not that bad.
Soldiers cannot jump as high as other characters, and I am bad at getting places with them. This is far more fruatrating than it sounds.


Verdict:
Excellent game. I really enjoy(ed) it. If you've never played a fighting game, or don't like them, or you're really bad, then this isn't the game for you. However, it is excellent for those who are willing to climb its learning curve.


Notes: This is my first review. My apologies if I've messed absolutely everything up and offended everyone in the general vicinity.
Also, my playtime is very inaccurate. I've played it offline most of the time. Supposedly the multiplayer is good, but I haven't bothered with it yet.

reviewText:
QUICK REVIEW:
+Wierd art style
+Fun RPG mechanics
+Interesting setting/characters
-iffy controls
Not sure what's up with all the negative reviews on this one
Anyway, this is basically a metroidvania with an actual combat system instead of basic attacks seen in most similar games.
ACE tried to capture the feel of a fighting game with the combat, as can be seen in the fact that literally every character/enemy in the game is playable in one way or another. All and all it feels out of place at first, but it's easy enough to get used to. Speaking of characters, the design of this game is unlike anything I've seen before; many of the monsters the player encounters are very interesting to look at, and often have eerie glowing or melting effects to them. This entire game really looks strange, yet at the same time great.
Other than that this is just an RPG rougelite where dying sends you back to the start without your equipment, but leveling and cash stay with you after death. I'm not the biggest fan of procedurally-generated enviroments, but the dungeon this game takes place in is varied enough to keep my attention.

In the end I have to say that this really is a good game. My only real complaint is that attack inputs often feel wonky or unresponsive since you're probably not going to learn the attacks of all the characters you play as.


Also a lot of people are complaining about co-op and KB/M controls.
Dunno anything about these; I've been playing this game alone with a 360 controller

reviewText:
Abyss Odyssey is a semi-difficult platformer rougelite. Let me take a moment to explain what I mean.
When I read the game description for this game I was assuming that this might be a game like rough legacy with some special moves thrown in and maybe a simple counter system. Because of this I went into this game with a button mashing mindset. The first few floors went by easy enough. But soon enough I found myself fighting against what seemed to be godlike baddies. They were blocking all my moves and striking me with ease. And when there was multiple eneimes I would just get slaughtered by them. Over and over I died. Earning a bit of exp and gold with each run I figured this was just one of the nonsense grind to get good games. Once I leveled up a bit and bought some nice impressive shiny gear I figured I was going to clear the game no problem... and then I was beaten to death once more.

To be honest I was thinking about giving up on the game, but slowing down a bit and taking the time to really understand what moves do and how the position you around your enemies I started  to understand the flow of this games combat. And once I took the time to learn about the cancel ablities the game started to become much easier.
Soon I did not care about gold or what gear I had. I was chaining my attacks and was destoying all in my path. I feel like you have total control in this game combat wise. You setup your fights, with how your use your abilities it almost seems like you can even controll the enemies movements. Combat is really rewarding in this game if you stick it out. And with three diffirent characters to try out you'll find someone with a playstill that is more comfortable for you to play with.

Though that does bring me to one nagative point I have with the game. Once you get combat down you find out just how short this game is. Of course the game does give you replayability. Whether you choose to grind for more exp, gold to buy the best gear to become godlike yourself, or maybe trying to clear the game again with a new character you'll still have something to do.

In short don't look into this game if you are looking for a simple button mashing game. The game can be difficult and seem almost unforgiving, but if you are looking for a game with rewarding game play and don't mind the rougelite mechanic of this game (nothing to bad here, if you die you just have to start over from the top gearless) I would reccomend giving this game a try.

reviewText:
A clunky fighter rogue-lite hybrid that, while decently fun despite he game handling like all your controller inputs were first translated by a monkey and then handed off the game developers who then decide whether or not your button press occurred or not, pretends to have much more depth on offer than it actually possesses. Collecting enemy souls isn't really that big of an appeal, they handle differently but each enemy type has one or two combos or moves that are just much better than the others and I find it difficult to want to invest time into learning how to handle this game knowing that my reward for high skill play is more monsters to learn.

Since the only thing you keep are levels and levels don't offer a significant enough increase from level to level the game feels the same the first time you beat and every time after that. You'll be strategically choosing monster souls based on what is and isn't good or what you do and don't know how to play which doesn't really encourage learning new ones even if the game throws a bonus stage with a random monster at you after every boss (actually this can be more annoying than exciting, having to learn a whole new moveset to fight a mob or two is actually pretty frustrating even if there isn't an actual penalty for losing.)

I want to like this game but the RPG and rogue-lite elements are limited, monster collecting doesn't appeal to me as it only serves to add a flimsy excuse to learn more about a game whose versus lobbies are deader than the extinct species list, and the storyline is only a bit interesting (less so when you realize you don't have any actual influence on it and reading about it doesn't actually give you any real benefit beyond a decently arranged story.) It's a decent game but it can only ever be decent when it is so riddled with flaws and the fact that the main menu contains an advertisement is just icing on the cake.

I can't recommend this purchase, I like it but it isn't where it would have to be for me to say you should pick this one up. If you really want to learn a clunky fighting game system so you can fight the same 12-15 enemies over and over then go right ahead but I'm not going to be the guy encouraging you to do it.

reviewText:
This game is kind of weird. It's like if Rogue Legacy, Smash Bros, Dark Souls, and Pokemon had a really messy orgy, and then this came out of it. The combat is slowish and satisfying, featuring emphasis on evasion and deliberate combos. You can capture Pokemon enemies and then transform into them, each with their own abilities and combos to learn.
There's co-op in this game but friendly fire makes it really difficult, and even with it disabled the increased number of enemies and bad camera control just turns your screen into a maelstrom of ♥♥♥♥. Co-op is still enjoyable though, but the game is much easier solo.
The production quality feels kind of scattered, the voice acting, graphics/art direction, and music aren't too bad (I like them a lot actually), but animation quality leaves a lot to be desired (although the choppiness is kind of funny). I also have a feeling that the game length has been cut shorter than planned, either that or the ending is just really ♥♥♥♥. Despite being short, the replay value of a rogue-lite still withstands.

I like this, get it on a sale or something if you enjoy rogue-likes and/or fighters. There's a Humble Bundle deal going on right now that ends Nov 10th and it's $1 for a 2-pack and some other games.

reviewText: This game is great. At first it can seem pretty difficult, but it's a game that requires some level of mastery. The way the combat system works is very similar to Super Smash Bros. There are shields, rolls, grabs, air dodges, directional attacks and aerial directional attacks. It handles differently though. It might take some time to get used to it even if you are familiar with Smash Bros. The campaign mode is like a randomly generated metroidvania with varying paths, monsters and bosses. There are multiple playable characters with all different skills, weapons, and movesets. You can even capture and switch between playing as your current character and a monster. The only negative things I can say about this game is 1) grabbing ledges is awful. You have to be really specific about how you approach the ledge. In some situations this can cost you a lot of health. 2) Sometimes you can get overwhelmed and wrecked by a group of enemies and/or stage hazards. They'll combo you to death if they attack you at the same time and get the first hit off. 3) Unavoidable hazards. There are some hazards that seemed too long to jump over. At least I couldn't make it with a double jump and dash/airdodge. I had to jump in and get poisoned. That's all the issues worth mentioning though. It's really good overall.

reviewText:
I don't know for sure, but so far this game is challenging and the combat DOES make sense if you actually bother to learn it. I enjoy the fighting. It can feel clunky if you're expecting a game where you can spam the ♥♥♥♥ out of your abilities. It's not one of those games. Like all platformers, use a controller for this one.

The art and music are both superb.

Add in random generated worlds, loss of equipment on death, and you've got a game kind of like Rogue Legacy, where you lose a lot on death but keep some progress (in this, you keep experience).

Co-op can be hard if you can't get over the friendly fire. Time your blocks, get out of each other's way, and it shouldn't be an issue.

If you like roguelikes and difficulty, this is for you.

reviewText:
+ visually striking, beutiful art style, and great animations.
+ soundtrack, fits the feeling of the game well.
+ combat, its deep for a 2D platformer.
+ rouge-like elements, when u die it is not a game over, u respawn back at the begining with starter items and all the gold u had at the time of death, and the other charecters react to that as it fits the story.  use the gold u collected before dying to get better gear to help u progress, buy tokens to set respawn points deeper in the dungeon, or save up to get better gear the next time u die.
+ interesting setting (I have not completed the story due to the game being hard as nails for me, but i did get to the lowest part of the dungeon and have played enough to comperhend most elements of the game)

~ the dungeon areas r randomized every time u die and respawn at the begining, i find that fun as it adds variety to the game, but some may find it annoying as the area diffeculties r also randomized.
~ diffeculty, u cant control it, each area in the dungeon has a diffeculty setting that is randomized unpon death regardless of how deep is that area.

- skills and leveling up, adding points to a certain skill doesn't seem to have much of an effect on the skill, and leveling up doesn't feel like it affects u that much.  and the fact that u can only have 3 skills upgraded and leaveing the other 2 without the effect of the upgrads can be annoying to some.
- learning curve, the game poorly explains all its mechanics early on, especially the combat combos and leveling up.
- length, the dungeon can be done in a very short amount of time if u have the personal skills and/or powerfull enough equipment, its the rouge-like nature of the game that add gameplay length.

reviewerDisplayName: as a group we perform better
reviewText:
This game is kind of weird. It's like if Rogue Legacy, Smash Bros, Dark Souls, and Pokemon had a really messy orgy, and then this came out of it. The combat is slowish and satisfying, featuring emphasis on evasion and deliberate combos. You can capture Pokemon enemies and then transform into them, each with their own abilities and combos to learn.
There's co-op in this game but friendly fire makes it really difficult, and even with it disabled the increased number of enemies and bad camera control just turns your screen into a maelstrom of ♥♥♥♥. Co-op is still enjoyable though, but the game is much easier solo.
The production quality feels kind of scattered, the voice acting, graphics/art direction, and music aren't too bad (I like them a lot actually), but animation quality leaves a lot to be desired (although the choppiness is kind of funny). I also have a feeling that the game length has been cut shorter than planned, either that or the ending is just really ♥♥♥♥. Despite being short, the replay value of a rogue-lite still withstands.

I like this, get it on a sale or something if you enjoy rogue-likes and/or fighters. There's a Humble Bundle deal going on right now that ends Nov 10th and it's $1 for a 2-pack and some other games.

Got it with the Humble Jumbo Bundle 5 and I loved the artwork in the trailer so I instantly downloaded it. I really like the art style in this game, it's brisk and unlike most things you see in modern games so it's also really fresh. The unfortunate point is that these two elements are the only things which I found good about the game. To have any idea about what you have to do you need to navigate to the help & options screen via the main menu. However once you've learnt the basic movements and actions they still feel really clunky and isn't very fluid at all. I've got to say I was really let down when I got into the game because of poorly the movements of the player controlled character were made.

TL;DR: Great artwork and sound track. Bad gameplay mechanics, feels like wasted potential.

reviewText:
Abyss Odyssey is a beautiful game with a nice gameplay and combat mechanics. It focus on the Hero/Soldier duality, when the Hero dies then a Soldier comes to continue it's progress. You have a chance to revive the Hero at an Altar if you make it that far. The Soldiers are weaker but still capable on their own and provide an interesting gameplay ideia: you're forced to do with the Soldiers what you could not do with the Hero.

The art style is incredible, all characters including enemies are very well design and the environments fit well within the game. The combat is varied and allows you to choose between 3 Heros + 3 Soldiers + about 20 different monsters you can summon once in a while. Each one has its own style and unique special abilities.

The game is a bit difficult, to get to the final boss you have to pass through many levels with different difficulties and if both your Hero and Soldier dies you're back to square one. There are checkpoints along the way to save progress but these require tokens which are quite expensive. Any attempt to defeat the final boss is an expedition that requires preparation and nerves of steel.

Pros:
- Amazing art style
- 3 heros to choose + a bunch of other playable characters
- Good combat
- Random generated levels improve replayability
- Made by the Zeno-Clash boys, guaranteed seal of Awesomeness

Cons:
- Controls are a bit slugish
- Better to play with Xbox controller
- Being bum-rushed to death happens from time to time
- Random generated levels end up being repetitive
- Difficulty

reviewText:
Abyss Odyssey is a semi-difficult platformer rougelite. Let me take a moment to explain what I mean.
When I read the game description for this game I was assuming that this might be a game like rough legacy with some special moves thrown in and maybe a simple counter system. Because of this I went into this game with a button mashing mindset. The first few floors went by easy enough. But soon enough I found myself fighting against what seemed to be godlike baddies. They were blocking all my moves and striking me with ease. And when there was multiple eneimes I would just get slaughtered by them. Over and over I died. Earning a bit of exp and gold with each run I figured this was just one of the nonsense grind to get good games. Once I leveled up a bit and bought some nice impressive shiny gear I figured I was going to clear the game no problem... and then I was beaten to death once more.

To be honest I was thinking about giving up on the game, but slowing down a bit and taking the time to really understand what moves do and how the position you around your enemies I started  to understand the flow of this games combat. And once I took the time to learn about the cancel ablities the game started to become much easier.
Soon I did not care about gold or what gear I had. I was chaining my attacks and was destoying all in my path. I feel like you have total control in this game combat wise. You setup your fights, with how your use your abilities it almost seems like you can even controll the enemies movements. Combat is really rewarding in this game if you stick it out. And with three diffirent characters to try out you'll find someone with a playstill that is more comfortable for you to play with.

Though that does bring me to one nagative point I have with the game. Once you get combat down you find out just how short this game is. Of course the game does give you replayability. Whether you choose to grind for more exp, gold to buy the best gear to become godlike yourself, or maybe trying to clear the game again with a new character you'll still have something to do.

In short don't look into this game if you are looking for a simple button mashing game. The game can be difficult and seem almost unforgiving, but if you are looking for a game with rewarding game play and don't mind the rougelite mechanic of this game (nothing to bad here, if you die you just have to start over from the top gearless) I would reccomend giving this game a try.

reviewText:
Abyss Odyssey is a platform based fighting game with a bit of story, a randomized map, and a whole lot of crazy. A major facet of the game is that death is not the end; not necessarily even in each playthough. When the main character, one of either Katrien, a dead dude with hands but no body, or a sea goddess, dies, they are simply replaced by a soldier (still playable, of course) who can revive the main at certain alters. Only when the soldier dies must you restart. However, death only costs you your progress down and your current one items. Level, exp, and gold are kept.
This game has a special mechanic that adds one more layer in. The main can use a special skill and rip the soul from an enemy, gaining the ability to transform into any enemy, including all bosses. Dying as a monster turns you back to the main, adding another layer of life. Which you will need because the monsters are brutally unmercifully good at beating you to a pulp. The AI is intelligent and each monster knows its strengths. If a monster is fast but weak and you shield, it'll wait for a hard hitter to show up and they will tag-team you to death.
The story (for characters, primarily. There isnt much of a plot.) and art of the game are amazing. The story is that a powerful warlock is in a asleep in a coma or something, and his nightmares are materializing in the real world. As one of his dreams, you are trying to stop him. Characters and monster are primarily from old Chilean myth and folklore and also a considerable amount from the Christian bible, plus many from various other worldwide myths, all with the wonderful wackiness of ACE. Plus there is also a crossover character from Zeno Clash now.


Pros:
Great visuals, music and designs.
Every character/enemy is playable.

Either way:
Difficulty. The game is brutal. There is no easy mode or tutorial. Only hard or harder. I like that, but not everyone does.
Enemies are really smart and know you, so you have to know and exploit them. Finding ways to successfully spam attacks is generally rewarded with not dying. You can do it, but so can the enemies, so it could go either way.
Animation cancelling is a major mechanic. This means that learning combos through hard trial and error is the best way and messing one up can mean a lost battle due to long animations. The mechanic is really cool though, so again, either way.

Cons:
Controls can be a tad floaty, but its not that bad.
Soldiers cannot jump as high as other characters, and I am bad at getting places with them. This is far more fruatrating than it sounds.


Verdict:
Excellent game. I really enjoy(ed) it. If you've never played a fighting game, or don't like them, or you're really bad, then this isn't the game for you. However, it is excellent for those who are willing to climb its learning curve.


Notes: This is my first review. My apologies if I've messed absolutely everything up and offended everyone in the general vicinity.
Also, my playtime is very inaccurate. I've played it offline most of the time. Supposedly the multiplayer is good, but I haven't bothered with it yet.

reviewText: This game is great. At first it can seem pretty difficult, but it's a game that requires some level of mastery. The way the combat system works is very similar to Super Smash Bros. There are shields, rolls, grabs, air dodges, directional attacks and aerial directional attacks. It handles differently though. It might take some time to get used to it even if you are familiar with Smash Bros. The campaign mode is like a randomly generated metroidvania with varying paths, monsters and bosses. There are multiple playable characters with all different skills, weapons, and movesets. You can even capture and switch between playing as your current character and a monster. The only negative things I can say about this game is 1) grabbing ledges is awful. You have to be really specific about how you approach the ledge. In some situations this can cost you a lot of health. 2) Sometimes you can get overwhelmed and wrecked by a group of enemies and/or stage hazards. They'll combo you to death if they attack you at the same time and get the first hit off. 3) Unavoidable hazards. There are some hazards that seemed too long to jump over. At least I couldn't make it with a double jump and dash/airdodge. I had to jump in and get poisoned. That's all the issues worth mentioning though. It's really good overall.

reviewText:
Short version:

Pros:
+satisfying combat
+beautiful visuals
+rogue-lite gameplay with some persistent progression
+procedurally generated levels
+unique fighting style for each playable unit
+worthy of multiple playthroughs
+coop

Cons:
-simple goal with little story
-fairly easy if you're good at this kind of side scrolling action
-controls are somewhat clunky at times
-a single play through is relatively short. game designed to be replayed (this can be a pro for some people i guess, since each play through does feel quite unique due to the randomly generated levels)
-no online versus mode



This game's controls feel a little bit clunky, but I don't think that takes away from the gaming experience too much. Once you get used to the controls, the combat system feels quite satisfying. It has enough depth and encourages varying moves. You can perform special cancel to chain up combo, throw enemies who keep on guarding, do a 360 degree attack against those who get behind you etc. Overall, the fighting mechanism actually feels quite like something you'd expect in a fighting game.

Each hero and other unit that you get to control has a unique move set. While some are arguably better than others (when playing as enemy units), They're still all interesting and fun to play as.

Coop is also fun. I always embrace games that include the coop feature. If you have a friend who to play with you, definitely check this out.

Gameplay wise, this game has a lot of rogue-lite elements. Levels are procedurally generated, and they offer a unique experience for every playthrough. Everytime you die, you'd have to restart from the beginning. The entire dungeon has to be cleared in one go and there is no in-dungeon saving. Also, if you die, all the items you're carrying are also gone. However, you do get to keep your levels, gold, and unlocked abilities, so there is a persistent progression. Because of the randomly generated levels and the uniqueness of each character, this game is certainly worthy of multiple playthroughs.

The visuals are beautiful. Backgrounds have an unusal amount of details for any randomly generated level.

However, there isn't a lot of story. the majority of the gameplay centers on combat and platforming with some exploration for hidden rooms and loot. A single playthrough is also relatively short, which is something i don't mind since i can replay it multiple times and still get a different experience in each playthrough. However, if you don't like replaying, then this might something you'd have to think about.

The game has a local versus mode, but puzzlingly it doesn't have online versus (but it does have online coop).

Overall, the game is fun, especially if you have a friend to play it with. Even if not, it is still worth getting for the single player expereince because of the randomly generated levels, which add a lot of replay value.

reviewText:
Genre: Fighting-Rougelike
Overall rating: 86%
Gameplay: 17/20
Sound/Music: 9/10
Graphics: 4/5 - Art design: 5/5
Controls: 3/5
Replay value: 5/5

Gameplay;
It's a fighting/platformer game with rouge-like elements. Combat works just like in a fighting game, every character/enemy has a proper move set, but instead of just a one screen arena, you have to fight through a randomized dungeon with multiple floors and paths.
The game has around 40 characters, three of them are main characters with the ability to capture enemy souls. This is one of the key features of the game, because once you capture a soul you can use that enemy/boss in the game. There are some ballance issues with this though, some are near worthless some are op and this can impact versus mode.
However it's not just a regular figthing game with platforming. The game has co-op and an inventory system, your main charactes can level up and gain skill points to strengthen moves they have found.

Sound/Music;
Music is excellent, sometimes reminds me of Castlevania, it creates a good atmosphere for the levels and characters. But it doesn't have any God tier" songs that I would put on my mp3 player so it's "just" a 9 out of 10.

Graphics;
Nothing extraordinary here

reviewText:
Why hello there friend. Say, do you enjoy ATLUS games? Do you enjoy roguelikes? Well how about fighting games, surely you enjoy those. If the answer to any or all of these questions was a resounding yes then I have some great news for you! Abyss Odyssey is a game which manages to combine all of those things into one complete package - and then some!

This game has beautiful visuals, strong atmosphere and easy to get into yet hard to master gameplay. The combat has more in common with a fighting game than a simple side scrolling action RPG, there are several quick button combos and cancels that can be performed across each character giving all of the heroes (of which there are 3) a unique feel. The core game mechanic is that of the roguelike, you will enter into the randomly generated abyss and proceed up ways and down ways and sideways and the like, each section offering new peril and new reward. If you enjoy games that have a dark yet almost serene atmosphere about them I would say this is definitely one to pick up, the game does a great job with its varying environment types within the abyss and the subtle musical accompaniments contribute to that package.

Like most roguelikes you can expect there to be a bit of a difficulty curve, items and levels will always be lost on death but your wealth will remain with you to make your next decent a bit easier. If you are on the fence about this one but you enjoy any of the things I mentioned above I would say go ahead and pick it up, it's worth it!

reviewText:
This game isn't perfect, but it's one I've really come to enjoy.

I'd definitely recommend playing this with a controller. My main complaint (which seems to be *the* complaint in general) is that the controls are a bit awkward. The combat took a little getting used to, but I got there in the end. Using the practice arena or the area before you select your entrance for the abyss helped me out. For some reason jumping is also oddly difficult, and looking at other reviews I'm glad to know it's not just me.

The replay value isn't the best (yet for some reason I personally find myself coming back to play more). Definitely give each character a shot though - I've found that I've enjoyed playing as Monk and Pincoya more than I've enjoyed playing as Katrien. Experiment with your special attacks and see what fits your personal style the best. It makes a massive difference.

The art in this game is truly amazing. My love for Art Nouveau became helplessly solid after playing this game! The music isn't bad, but sometimes I'm just not in the mood for it and I turn it down and play whatever else I want instead. The game alt+tabs with no worries, but the pause menu doesn't seem to be a pause in the expected sense, but when it pauses you can still take damage when you're in the middle of a fight. There are clever and interesting references to various mythology and other games throughout the game, and I didn't pick them all up straight away. It was nice to realise them later.

I paid full price for this game and I don't feel ripped off. However, I know not everyone else feels the same way. I recommend the game, though. Ultimately it's a fun and beautiful game that I fell and love with and I keep coming back to, despite some of its flaws.

reviewText: I really loved the idea of having a 2d rogue-like beat'em up, but the game *feels* really sluggish: the animation is really fluid, but hitframes are very hard to manage and turning is just weird (and slow), it feels like fighting in water or underwater even. On the other hand the art style is nice, the art nouveau stills are beautiful - but as a dungeon crawler beat'em up this is a no-no, at least for me.

reviewText: Nothing is more disheartening than missed potential. The concept is full of promise, but the execution is lacking. The controlls are stiff and feel far too unresponsive for this kind of gameplay. The procedurally generated dungeon still manages to feel linear and never throws anything unexpected your way. After about an hour, the game feels more like a grind than exploration. A little more polish could have made this game exceptional.
